DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate without amendment.
Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the estimates for the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance I wish to focus particularly on the economic growth rates which these departments oversee. The growth rates for Australia since this Government came to office have been real and sustained. In 1984-85 economic growth rates were forecast and were on target at 5 per cent for non-farm growth and 4.6 per cent for total gross domestic product. Economic growth is forecast to continue at 5 per cent this financial year. This will enable the job seekers in Australia to widen their employment prospects. This performance contrasts markedly with the Appropriation Bills brought down by the previous Government. When we came to office the Australian economy was ravaged. Negative growth rates were recorded for the first time in 30 years. Unemployment had risen by a quarter of a million in the previous year. We were left with a deficit of $9.6 billion which, if left untended, would have been absolutely ruinous for every man and woman in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Initially our growth rates impacted greatest in the public sector. This was the essential place to kick-start the economy. As the growth rates have continued, our reliance on the public sector has been wound back. The Department of the Treasury forecasts that this year the public sector will contribute less than a sixth of overall growth compared with more than a third last year. This will reduce the deficit further and will substantially reduce the public sector borrowing. The discipline the Commonwealth has imposed upon itself also has important ramifications for external accounts directly and indirectly. Directly, public sector borrowings abroad are being moderated. Indirectly, reduced public borrowings will have some counterpart in reduced lending to Australia by the rest of the world. The outcome for taxes, outlays and the deficit fully meets our trilogy of fiscal commitments and our commitment to reduce the deficit in money terms. This is the first time it has been met in 17 years.

There has been much misleading talk recently of the Government amassing a huge debt overseas. A well-known businessman, Mr John Leard, placed advertisements in the Australian asserting that as much as $70 billion was being borrowed overseas. In reality, there is no net Commonwealth overseas debt. The Commonwealth overseas debt is equal to the Commonwealth's holdings of gold and foreign currency. Something like $13 billion of State government and State guaranteed debt is owed externally. The rest of the $52 billion is privately owned debt. Some supposed finance experts have been running around, particularly on the Darling Downs, alleging that the country is in trouble because of the debt. No wonder business in my State is in such a mess if that is the quality of advice given. I note that the appropriations deal with the Australian Taxation Office. As a result of initiatives undertaken by this Government, taxation officers will have the privilege of administering a fairer taxation system. The recently announced tax changes give genuine relief to the honest, law abiding taxpayer. I am also pleased that whilst giving incentive to those who earn large incomes, the new system also recognises those in need of assistance.

In debating the Treasury appropriation, I am pleased to be able to refer to the previous head of Treasury. Unlike the present Department heads, the immediate past head has taken a quantum intellectual leap backwards. Indeed his cerebral decay is so advanced that he actually agrees with the Premier of Queensland on, of all things, a flat rate of tax. To date, however, unlike the Queensland Premier, I do not think Mr Stone believes that cars run on water. It is interesting to speculate why Mr Stone never seriously advanced a flat rate of tax when he was in a position to do something about it.

In discussing Treasury appropriations, it is interesting to speculate why a flat rate of tax was not put forward by the Treasury. Perhaps the main reason is that a 25 per cent flat rate of tax would make every taxpayer in Australia earning less than $23,000 a year worse off. That would be about 85 per cent of all Australian taxpayers. A taxpayer with a $13,000 income would be $22 a week worse off. A taxpayer on $17,000 a year would pay $18 a week extra tax under a flat rate system and someone on $20,000 a year would pay $13.30 a week extra taxation. The flat rax rate would result in a tax increase of about $2,000 for a farmer on average levels of farm income. That is what Mr Stone, the Queensland National Party and the Federal National Party hope will be the new wave of taxation measures. I challenge the Queensland Premier to tell the voters in Redlands why he would tax them an extra $18 a week.

The former Treasury head said that the 25 per cent flat tax rate could be reduced to 20 per cent with government restraint. Assuming that the deficit would be the same size, a 20 per cent flat tax rate applied now would require a cut in government outlays of the order of $12 billion to $13 billion. The Queensland Premier and the Federal National Party have not cared to comment on exactly how they would like to cut back this amount of money. The Queensland Premier went off squealing after the Premiers Conference, yet he advocates a system that would bring about enormous reduction in State revenues.

The Queensland Government has never been able to reduce government spending by anything near the amount of money it would need to finance a flat rate of tax. Indeed, Queensland has the highest per capita deficit in Australia. I suggest that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) should lend his Treasury officials to Queensland as an act of mercy on the long-suffering Queensland population. As I look at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development survey with its glowing predictions for Australia, I wonder why my State of Queensland is performing so disastrously. Queensland has the highest rate of unemployment of any State. It has the largest number of working days lost per 1,000 employees through industrial disputes and, in that respect, has almost doubled the national average number of working days lost. It had the smallest growth in new dwelling commencements for the 12 months ended March 1985. That represents an improvement in Queensland of only one half of one per cent. In the rest of Australia the average was 14 per cent.

Queensland has the second lowest rate of inflation decline. In the March quarter of 1985, fixed private capital investment in Queensland declined by 3.4 per cent while in the rest of Australia it increased by 11.1 per cent. Most importantly, there was a 24 per cent increase in the number of bankruptcies in Queensland when the number of bankruptcies in Australia, on average, fell by almost 5 per cent. Unfortunately, Queensland is the sick State of the nation. It has not shared the prosperity which has been brought to this country.

The great difference between the appropriations in this Parliament and the ones in the Queensland Parliament is performance. As the Treasurer has said, this is a can do government. It has set out to get the fundamentals of the economy right. (Quorum formed) Obviously members of the National Party of Australia do not like to know the truth about Queensland, that is it is run by an aging megalomaniac. They are very susceptible to criticism. In Queensland the National Party is motivated by hype rather than any realistic assessment of the true position of the economy. Like a reversion to the ancient tradition of the cargo cult, the National Party announces multi-million dollar projects that never eventuate. One such project is the rolling steel mill to be built in Carole Park in my electorate. This has been promised for many years and nothing has happened. In the early 1980s Brisbane Mini Steel Mills Pty Ltd discussed a steel mill proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech of the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) was not a very profound defence of the Government's policies relating to this country's external problems and the difficulties associated with our massive external debt. There is a dominant factor in the present economic scene, a crucial point which should not be out of our minds for a moment, although the Government hardly ever mentions it directly in all its rhetoric about Australia having 5 per cent growth and an increase in the number of jobs that the Government, to use its quaint phrase, has created. It is precisely the fact that this country is living beyond its means. It has been now for two to three years, and it is a situation that as for an individual, cannot go on indefinitely.

SPEECH.PARA: The most visible and culpable manifestation of this is the Hawke Government's succession of massive Budget deficits-$8 billion in 1983-84, $6.7 billion in 1984-85, and with an effective deficit of near $6 billion this year. Although there has been economic recovery and growth, as the Government constantly reminds us and which is gratifying, we would expect that by now a responsible government would have reached the stage where it could live more within its means. However, the problem of the nation living beyond its means goes further and wider than just the Government; it raises the whole question of the nation's standard of living generally; of the appropriateness and sustainability of that standard of living. In fact, the situation has rightly been described as one of fundamental national economic disequilibrium. This national `living beyond our means' shows up in the balance of international payments. The deficit there in 1984-85-the excess on what we had to pay for imports and in interest on that massive external debt, over what we earned from exports-was at an all time high of $10.2 billion in that year. Well, we meet that by borrowing in one form or another, but because of the increasing size of that external deficit the judgment of the international community has been visited upon us in the form of the depreciation of the Australian dollar of the order of 20 per cent.

It is worth noting the impact that depreciation has on our external debt. With borrowing last year of the order of $10 billion, and the depreciation of 20 per cent applied to the whole external debt-in effect adding $10 billion-the debt increased by over $20 billion to a gross total of nearly $70 billion, requiring in the order of 33 per cent of our export income to service it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still rising.

—My colleague says that it is still rising. Indeed in 1985-86 we are on the way to another $10.7 billion deficit in the balance of payments. That is likely to be exacerbated by energy and other commodity price weaknesses that have been reported lately. On the positive side, the devaluation of the Australian dollar is, or should be, the beginning of the readjustment process. Given a chance to work, it will have the effect of reducing imports and increasing exports, thus moving the adverse balance of payments situation in the right direction, and also it encourages economic activity in Australia. Indeed, the basic economic strategy of the Budget that we are discussing is precisely a devaluation-led dash for further economic growth. The important point is the qualification I mentioned-that it should be given the chance to work. In the Budget Speech, the Treasurer recognised what is required. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the face of a slowing world economy we must increase our share of markets to pay our way as a nation. This means we must stay competitive and if we are to do that, we cannot afford to allow our production costs to rise above those of our competitors. If the initial and full price effects of the depreciation were to be transmitted to wages via indexation decisions, our cost increases would noticeably exceed those of our major competitors for years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —And then they do a deal with the unions.
—I was coming to that. My colleague anticipates me. The Treasurer continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Our competitive edge would be lost. . . We would be throwing away any prospect of sustaining the growth rates required to get unemployment down. That is why, temporarily, we must modify our normal support for full wage indexation.
He continued:
In the next two wage indexation cases the Government will argue before the full bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that the price effects of the depreciation be taken into account.

That is what the Treasurer said in his Budget Speech. What happened then? Quite simply, as my colleague said, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Government's master in this as in tax matters, said no. The prices and incomes accord, that much vaunted instrument of policy that seems to have received such a build-up in recent days, makes no provision for taking the price effects of devaluation into account. Still, it could be bent, and it was bent, and a deal was done.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could mean a 12 per cent increase in wages this year.

—It could, but it starts off with a full 3.8 per cent indexation request in the September case and puts off until next April a discounting of 2 per cent. By then, these price effects will be well in excess of such a discounting of the adjustment of wages to prices. This 3.8 per cent increase in wages and other related on-costs, fuelled by the rapid expansion of credit, will feed into price levels in 1986 and put this country on a course of costs and prices rising well above those of our competitors. I have no hesitation in stating that a 2 per cent discount next April is both inadequate and too long delayed-indeed, fatally delayed. The result will be that the effect of the depreciation in correcting the massive balance of payments deficit will be largely inoperative, so the borrowing will continue, the nation's overseas debt will continue to grow, and our national credit status will fall even further.

SPEECH.PARA: Over recent weeks we have seen a concerted attempt to paint the prices and incomes accord as entirely beneficent-indeed, indispensable-to the conduct of overall economic policy. I can understand what the Treasurer is attempting to do in principle, namely, to restrain wages directly through the accord, in order to pursue more expansionary fiscal and monetary policies and thus achieve a higher level of economic activity and employment, with less inflation than otherwise would be possible. Yet, I submit that over the whole period of the Government's term of office the level of award wages-from the initial 4 per cent increase in the September 1983 case through to this present accord Mark II deal with the ACTU to which I have just referred-has been at least as high as, if not higher than, would have been the case under a different system. Increases outside the award system, which the unions are supposed to eschew in return for full indexation, have also been significant. While there has been significant economic growth, the Hawke Government's excessively expansionary fiscal and monetary policy has resulted only in a massive balance of payments deficit; the weak Australian dollar; record high interest rates; very likely double digit inflation next year; and unemployment, albeit down on the latest figures by a fraction of a decimal point or two, pretty sticky and at a level higher than that which prevailed throughout six of the seven years of the Fraser Government. I conclude by saying that the world's best Treasurer had better batten down for some pretty heavy weather ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting time in the national economic debate because the Opposition is trying to cobble together a philosophy and an approach to economics at the same time as the Government has put together an economic performance which is beginning to show results. It is interesting to compare the performance in terms of statistics with what we are getting from the Opposition. While the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) has some distinction in the area of economics, I hope that he does not fall into the current Opposition strategy of appearing to yap yap away on economic matters. The honourable member for Berowra has made a contribution to the economic debate in this country, but I hope that he will not fall into the position of stringing together this sort of rhetoric and appearing to yap around in terms of economic performance. The substantial economic picture is that the Australian economy is performing very well. I am mindful of what the honourable member for Berowra said about the external debt and I propose to debate that in just a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: If we talk to people in the Australian community, they are mindful of the fact that jobs are available, the economy is performing, price increases have been reduced, housing in particular is now on a substantial upturn, and the economy, compared with that of three years ago, is markedly improved. Those opposite cannot get away from that. They have to recognise that in the context of debates of this kind, if they come in here and cast around a few figures they run the risk of appearing to be like small dogs yapping at the heels of the Australian community. That will not work because the community will not accept it. It is more realistic and down to earth in its understanding of the way things work. The community can cut through the nonsense that sometimes is debated in this place. I think it is important and instructive for all of us on both sides of the chamber-I say this in good faith to the honourable member for Berowra-to remember that the Australian community is not about to be conned by any government or by any opposition.

The Opposition is under considerable pressure at the moment, because the Australian community is waiting for it to come up with a wages policy. There is not one, and that is well known. Let us think for the moment of the proposition of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) which concerns deregulation. The Leader of the Opposition has said: `Let us deregulate wages, let us have free bargaining'. Can honourable members really imagine a 17-year-old who has been unemployed for six months going to a senior manager of a metals company or a building company and saying: `I am here to bargain about my wages, to strike a contract with you'? That is not a realistic proposition. Nor is it realistic-I think this is a substantial point-for the Opposition to talk about deregulating wages. I ask honourable members to imagine a circumstance in which wages were freed up completely, as the Leader of the Opposition proposes. What would an employer do? Would he keep on a man who had a wife and three children, a house and a mortgage and so on on a salary of $300 a week or would he put on an 18-year-old on $200 a week? I put that proposition to the Opposition. Quite logically, the employer would put on the person who cost less.

What is the implication of that? Is the Opposition really saying that it favours a situation in which mature-aged Australians, be they men or women, with families will be pushed out of the work force? That is the substance, the outcome, of what the Opposition is saying. If we enter into a free bargaining situation the lowest bidder will always win. The Leader of the Opposition himself admitted in a radio program on Perth radio 6PR that a $100 a week wage differential was a real possibility. He then resorted to saying: `Well, employers are more benevolent than that. They really would not take advantage of that situation'. I suggest that employers are sensible economic people. They would take advantage of that situation and they would employ the person on the lower wage. What would we see? We would see considerable disturbance for ordinary Australian people, and the ordinary Australian people who are listening to this debate would understand that very clearly.

On that first count, the Opposition's current performance on wages, is very shaky indeed. Fortunately, some others in the Opposition have said: `No, we will stay with centralised wage fixation because it makes sense'. I know that the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) in particular is one who supports that proposition. It is a substantial one and I think we have to recognise that.

The Opposition has not yet delivered on wages. It has not yet delivered on taxes, either. We still have before us the extraordinary flat tax, flat earth proposition of some on the other side, and some other notions are being introduced about using section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act for a capital gains tax, and so on. There really is considerable confusion. The community recognises that confusion, too. It recognises that the Opposition has not worked it through. Let us contrast that with the statistics. A headline in this morning's Australian Financial Review says: `Jobless rate down to lowest in three years'. That is not a rhetorical invention; it is a reality. We have a substantial reduction in unemployment. In the last year of the previous Government some 250,000 jobs were lost. We have seen a substantial turnaround. Since March 1983 we have created 487,000 new jobs, and that is related to the increasing work force participation.

Not only are people more confident about the economy and coming back into the work force, but they are coming back at an increasing rate. At the same time, with the support of the private sector, we are creating jobs at a rate fast enough to absorb them and so reduce net unemployment. That is a substantial achievement, and people in the community know that. Despite all the comments and all the rhetoric that go on in here, the community understands very clearly that the job situation is improving. The statistics support that proposition, but so do the community's own perceptions, every day.

Also, we have substantial economic growth. In the years of the Liberal governments we saw an average economic growth of 2.1 per cent. We are looking at an average economic growth under the two Hawke Governments of some 5 per cent-and that is substantial. We have a non-farm gross domestic product of 4.5 per cent to 5 per cent. It is not good enough for the Opposition to say that we are in a state of crisis. We are not; the economy is growing.

I wish to devote just a moment to the question of external debt. The Opposition is not saying to the Australian community, as it ought to be-it is attempting to mislead the community-that a substantial part of the growth in external debt has been in private sector borrowings. People are currently very much aware of enormous activity on Australian stock exchanges. That activity, in part, is being funded by external borrowings. In fact, growth in the external private sector debt has been far greater than growth in the public sector external debt. We on this side of the chamber are mindful of the difficulties created by increasing external debt, but the reality is that a substantial amount of that growth is occurring in the private sector. That is not to say that we should wash our hands of it and say that it is not the responsibility of the Government, but we have to recognise that, if there is borrowing, it is borrowing for a purpose. The purpose in this instance is to try to get money into the Australian economy to participate in economic growth. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in his Budget statement, we are about getting this economy back to work; this economy is back in business. Australia is back in business, and people understand that very well. Whilst our external debt position is not altogether satisfactory, we have to recognise that a substantial amount of that debt lies in the private sector.

I wish also to devote a moment to the question of interest rates. The Opposition is making much of interest rates at the moment. We also have some members of the Opposition saying: `Let us deregulate housing interest rates'. That is a very sinister proposition, because the deregulation of housing interest rates would mean that the current housing interest rates would go up by some 2 per cent. Is the Opposition really saying that it wants ordinary Australians to pay an extra 2 per cent on their housing interest rates? We on this side are very clear on this matter. We would not wear that. We believe that housing is an important part of the economy. We also believe that people deserve to get into housing, unlike the Opposition which, when it was in government, began to put about the proposition that people would have to learn to live without housing.

In conclusion, I believe that the position is clear. The Opposition is putting around a bit of rhetoric about its position. It is not clear, and the community knows it. The Government's position has become very clear. The number of jobs has grown, the economy is growing substantially, inflation is being reduced and Australia is back in business. The community understands that, and so does the Government.

What he said was basically the same as the proposition which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has brought before the Parliament. SPEECH.PARA: I know what the Treasurer says about the gross domestic product, a lower inflation rate and all the other issues. That all sounds good, but in reality I cannot see this. I do not want to be a pessimist. I think we have to be optimists at all times. We have to go around our electorates pumping up the thoughts, the endeavours and the motivation of people to do well and expand. I do not blame only the Government for the situation but I wonder whether all governments over the last couple of decades have really planned for the future of Australia, for what can be expected of this nation. Government should play an important role concerning our ability to enter world trade and supply the food, materials and minerals that this world demands. Perhaps if we were good Christian folk, good moral folk, better than we are purported to be, we would be paying more attention to these matters and ensuring that this nation can express in practical terms what basically is expected of us.

I know that the unemployment level has come down to 8.l3 per cent or 8.2 per cent, but let us not forget that, as the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) said a week or so ago, there are 60,000 people employed under the community employment program. I rose to speak very briefly about the actual allocations within the Department of the Treasury of administration funds to cope with the new tax reforms which the Treasurer has introduced. Have any of us ever stopped to think of what will occur within an accountant's office or a business office or what will happen in relation to our own affairs as members of parliament as a result of the tax on fringe benefits? What about all the dockets and the accounts? I ask honourable members to think of the work we will have to do when we take these to our accountants.

I ask honourable members to think of the work involved for people in big and small industries and for farmers out in the field. Let us think of what the farmer and his wife will have to do to accommodate their accountants and legal advisers with information. Look at the tremendous expense we will thrust on the people of Australia as a result of the taxation reform-that added burden which the people of this country complain about today. The other day I said to an accountant who has 15 people on his staff that in two years he would have 30 people on his staff just to cope with these iniquitous measures. People will have to pay for accountancy and legal advice as a result of those.

Let us look at what will happen when that work is transferred to the Taxation Office. For example, if there is a query about a bad assessment, look at all the extra information and advice which will have to be supplied by the accountant and by the person concerned. This must mean a tremendous amount of extra expenditure by the Treasury on its administration to look after its tax affairs.

This will be the outcome of all the things we were debating yesterday and which we will talk about next week in the Parliament. This taxation reform involves extra cost burdens and worries which will be thrown on people. For aged people the assets test is quite enough worry without these extra things. Is there any need for this extra worry? Surely there is some simple tax reform or a simple taxation system that could be introduced by this Government-which we could assist with-which would make it simple for the Australian people to use. Surely there is something that would be easy for people to comply with. Surely there is no need for all the intricate matters which we are debating and talking about here today. I would love the Treasurer to say what plans the Treasury has made to cope with all these extra matters it will have to deal with.

I have one further worry. This worry relates to money owed by the Government. If anybody owes the Government money he has to pay it. However, if the Government owes a person money-for example, for the resumption of land or for services or something of that kind-how long does that person have to wait? I ask the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) how often he has had to make representations to a government department on behalf of citizens within his electorate for a matter to be finalised. I am doing that kind of thing continually.

At the moment I am making representations to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) about a matter concerning an area of land surrounding the Salt Ash weapons range. Two farmers who have worked hard for a lifetime are still waiting on the finalisation of business relating to a large area of land to be acquired by the Defence Department. Why should these people have to wait? For example, if the citizen owes the government money for a taxation assessment and he cannot pay, he has to pay 20 per cent interest on that money owing. What does the government pay the citizen out in the field to whom it owes money? The government does not pay interest. This is not very fair. This matter applies not only to the Federal Government but also to municipal or shire councils. This is a little lopsided. I think these things should be said. We should be aware that this is a parliament of the citizens. We should be reacting accordingly. Those are the issues I wanted to raise in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with my distinguished colleague the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), I have been moved to enter this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) following the reassuring tone of Government members. I suggest that those assertions of reassurance that all is well in the rose garden are either representative of the height of naivety or somewhat approaching deliberate falsehoods because, as all those people in small business and the rural production sectors of our economy know, things are not good.

SPEECH.PARA: It has always been, for the most part at least, that big business and, certainly, big unions can take care of themselves. I wish to direct my brief remarks in this debate to those people caught between those two extremes, namely, small businessmen and rural producers. Those people know that they cannot get ahead, let alone get started, because of the impost of high interest rates which are the direct result of this Government's policy, because of increasing inflation and because of skyrocketing government costs and charges. I concede however that much of the responsibility for Government costs and charges falls within the bounds of State and local government as well as the Federal Government.

On top of that we have a problem with a rigid labour market and indexed wages which does not take into account the capacity of small private sector participants to pay. Anybody involved in small business or farming knows that the picture is not as the Government seeks to portray it. The true picture is that nobody can get started in business because of, firstly, the non-availability of finance and, secondly, the cost of that finance. I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who tells us that he was a very successful small businessman before assuming parliamentary responsibilities, to tell us how he would start a business today in the meat processing trade. How could he as an individual with all the initiative and drive he displayed years ago start a business today and get it off the ground? I would be very interested to hear the Minister's answer.

Figures released recently by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that there is almost an equal number of people receiving either government pensions or employed by governments as there are people employed within the private sector. That means that for every person creating wealth and engaged in the private sector there is someone else to consume that wealth or, in the case of public servants, there is someone to distribute the wealth and to consume it in the form of wages. That is putting the situation in a nutshell.

Big unions and big business have an undue influence on this Government. The small businessman and the farmer are caught and being squeezed between those two. Unless this Government, by way principally of taxation reform, looks at eliminating the impost on the small businessman and farmer these people will not get ahead and the results for this country will be devastating. The lack of competitiveness of our overseas trading exports is increasingly clear to the Australian electorate. The cost of huge government borrowings in terms of billions of dollars also is becoming very well known. Always the losers in this trend towards big government, big unions and big business are those people engaged in small business and the farmers. I seek the Minister's response not just to the specific question I put to him but also to how this Government, principally through taxation policy, will alleviate the burdens-and the resultant effect on the Australian economy-on small farmers and small businessmen.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up this part of the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86 on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), I am inspired to say that there was a marked contrast between the positive contributions by the two Government members, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), and the speeches from the Opposition side. The honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) are two of the more highly respected senior members of the Opposition; their words are usually listened to with interest. I felt almost a feeling of sorrow. I could feel the envy coming through in their speeches for the way in which the Government has turned the economy around. In some ways, because they are decent Australians, there is a sense of satisfaction with the Government's achievements in the economic area because certainly there was nothing to point to in the previous seven years of their own government that in any way matched the achievements of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up, I make reference to a few of the points of the economy that are worth speaking to and then perhaps I will relate a comment or two to the contributions of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). In terms of economic growth, non-farm growth in Australia for the last two years has been 5 per cent and will probably be in excess of that for this year. Australia's growth rate has become the envy of the other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations and is more than twice the growth rate achieved by the previous Government in its seven years of office, which was a rather poor 2.1 per cent. I guess the best way we can measure confidence is in terms of consumption. Retail sales continue to rise strongly. They increased by 4.3 per cent in the July quarter to be 11.2 per cent higher than in the July quarter of 1984. I think it should bring joy not only to members of this chamber but to all Australians that Australians at last have hope and confidence in their nation and that instead of squirreling their money away in savings banks they are out spending it. That is the reason why our work force has risen so dramatically.

In relation to the labour market, employment grew strongly in the year to September, rising by 210,900 jobs. The Government promised 500,000 new jobs in three years. Six months short of the three-year time span we are only 13,000 jobs short of target. In that period 487,000 jobs have been created in Australia. That is almost the total number of jobs that have been produced in the previous 10 years in Australia, including the seven years of the previous Government. The unemployment rate is down from 10.4 per cent in September 1983 to 8.1 per cent in September 1985. That figure is rather misleading anyhow because the expectations of Australians about getting jobs have risen to the extent that a lot more people are now registering as unemployed who, under the previous Government, had given up. With a large increase of jobs, that unemployment figure should be treated with a certain amount of reserve.

One of the great indications of prosperity in the community is in the housing sector. In 1984-85 commencements numbered 152,000 units, which is the highest level since 1973-74. Of course, that amount of investment is spread over the whole of Australia in regional as well as in city areas. In the three months to August 1985 the number of approvals rose by 1.2 per cent. In terms of real private business fixed investment, we have recovered in 1984-85 by 4 per cent. The Australian Statistician shows that in current prices investment expectations are 11 per cent higher for 1985-86. In real terms we expect growth to be a little higher than last year. No matter which area of the economy we look at there is economic growth. That is the reason why I respect the comments of the honourable member for Berowra, who is a former Professor of Economics at the Macquarie University. That is why I am sure there is a little envy in Dr Edwards's comments because I know that as a proud Australian he is pleased to see the economy rise.

I must relate some comments to the honourable member for Gippsland, who referred to my own experience in small business. I am quite happy to tell him that despite the best efforts of the cockies with whom I deal in my particular business, or rather with whom my partner deals these days, we have had a record year. It is the best year I have ever had. I am sure that that translates itself down to everybody in business in Australia. While his comments may have fallen on some people's ears, I think that they are treated with a fair amount of reserve because there is a confidence, a hope and a prosperity in the Australian business area that has not been evident for many, many years.

While thanking everybody for their comments in this debate, I must reiterate that the Government stands proudly on its economic record over the last three years and I am sure that every proud and patriotic Australian, including a lot of members of the Opposition, will share in the joy and the belief that the Australian economy has been turned around and that we can look forward to a good number of years of increasing prosperity under this Government.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House seeks to make a number of important changes in a variety of fields relating to the health portfolio. First, the Bill proposes substantial amendments to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Act 1961 to increase the competitive ability and the autonomy of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Secondly, it proposes significant reforms to the medifraud provisions of the Health Insurance Act 1973. Thirdly, it provides, under a sunset clause, for the Health Insurance Commission to undertake planning and development of the Australia Card. Finally, it provides for a number of amendments mainly of a technical nature to various aspects of the health function.

I first draw the attention of honourable members to Part II of the Bill which is intended to streamline greatly the day-to-day operations and to improve the commercial viability of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories-or CSL-Commission. The need for these important changes has become apparent since the CSL Act was last amended in 1980, following an independent inquiry into the Commission's operations and capital works. These changes are the most significant changes to the structure and operations of CSL in its 69-year history. Clause 10 of the Bill seeks to enable CSL to make use of idle production facilities and resources when they are not being used for pharmaceutical production. The additional use of CSL's facilities in this way will, of course, decrease the overall cost of operations to the Commonwealth. Clause 11 will allow the Commission to undertake a number of normal commercial activities such as forming a company, buying and selling shares, or entering into a profit-sharing partnership. This clause removes a current constraint on CSL which is not imposed on its competitors and is intended to make the Commission more commercially viable in a highly competitive industry. I would point out that any transactions of this nature will require the Minister's approval where CSL will have a controlling interest. Clause 20 provides for possible reimbursement to the Commission if, as a result of a direction given to it by the Minister, it suffers a financial loss.

Other provisions in the Bill are designed to help the Commission improve its efficiency, effectiveness and accountability. I will briefly outline some of these matters: The current constraint which prevents any person with a direct or indirect interest in any pharmaceutical enterprise from appointment as a CSL commissioner is to be removed. The term of appointment for commissioners is to be changed from the current four years to not less than three and not more than five years. These two changes will broaden the range of people eligible and available for appointment. A legislative requirement for declaration of interests by commissioners is being introduced, formalising a practice which has existed for many years. The Commission's Director, whose title is to be changed to Managing Director, will in future be appointed by the Commission itself, rather than by the Governor-General. Such changes recognise the importance of the chief executive officer and the controlling body of a government authority which is expected to be competitive and commercially viable and to play a leading role in public health in Australia. In relation to Commission staff, the requirement for Public Service Board approval of staff terms and conditions is removed-a necessary step to allow the Commission to be more innovative and competitive in the labour market place. The Minister will be required to consult with the Commission before giving it any written direction which will affect its operations; such direction will have to be published in the Commonwealth Gazette within 21 days. The Commission is to be covered by the general provisions of the Audit Act 1901 in relation to its accountability.

These are the principal changes proposed in the part of the Bill relating to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission-changes which will enhance the operations and the commercial effectiveness of the Commission. In relation to the financial impact of the changes, in only one area is there any possibility of a cost to the Government. I refer to the possible reimbursement to the Commission for any financial loss resulting from a direction given by the Minister. Such a direction would be given only as a last resort following consultation with the Commission and after other avenues of action in accordance with the legislation has been exhausted. It is impossible to quantify such a cost; it would depend entirely on the circumstances at the time.

On the other hand, an increase in revenue for the Government is expected. The improved commercial viability of the Commission should produce increased dividends. In addition, cost savings for the Government can be expected from the increased use of production facilities. These changes will further prove the advantages to Australian citizens of having a public window into the pharmaceutical industry.

I now turn to a number of provisions in the Bill which propose amendments to the Health Insurance Act. Section 3B of the Act currently provides for the issue of a certificate by a medical practitioner stating that a person is in need of acute hospital care for a period of up to 35 days. The section ensures that full benefits are paid for long term acute care hospital patients. Without this certification all patients are automatically classified as `nursing home type patients' after 35 days in hospital and their health fund benefits are reduced accordingly. Experience has shown that, for various reasons, medical practitioners sometimes fail to furnish certificates at the appropriate time. As there is currently no retrospectivity allowed by the legislation, some acute care patients have been financially disadvantaged through reduction of their hospital benefits to nursing home levels. It must be pointed out, however, that the health insurance industry has behaved most responsibly in this area, and has usually made ex gratia benefit payments in such circumstances.

Clause 28 of this Bill proposes that retrospective certification be allowed; it has the support of the health insurance and private hospital industries, and of the Australian Medical Association. The amendment will correct a current anomaly under which the health funds cannot share the liability for ex gratia payments via the reinsurance arrangements. Commonwealth outlays will not be affected, as the Commonwealth bed-day subsidy continues to be paid whether the patient is classified as `nursing home type' or `acute care'.

The Bill proposes a further change to this section of the Health Insurance Act-an amendment of the definition of `nursing-home type patient' in sub-clause 26 (2) and a provision in clause 27 which together enable the Secretary to my Department to exclude individual patients or classes of patients from the nursing home type patients arrangements. This would be done through a determination which would be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance. To ensure proper consideration of the medical circumstances of each case, the determination power would be delegated to senior Commonwealth medical officers within my Department.

The development of a review process through the Acute Care Advisory Committee arrangements, plus monitoring of the nursing-home type patient arrangements, has pointed to some justification for the exclusion of certain types of patients from those arrangements. These might include, for example, certain long term acute care psychiatric patients and terminally ill cancer patients. The types of patients who might be covered by this amendment are to be discussed with the medical profession and the health insurance organisations before any individuals or class of exclusion is declared. The purpose of this amendment is to provide an appropriate mechanism to allow an exclusion of general classes of patients, whereas currently only individual exclusions are permitted.

Again, there will be no effect on Commonwealth outlays, nor will health insurance organisations be affected as it is intended that any excluded class of patients would be those to whom section 3B certificates now routinely apply. There should be a small administrative saving through a reduction in the numbers of certificates issued by doctors and monitored by the health funds.

Clause 37 will amend section 20 of the Health Insurance Act to empower the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission to determine how Medicare benefits should be paid. The new provision is similar to one in the social security legislation. The Commission has always followed a policy of limiting cash payments for Medicare claims at its branch offices, with benefits above a certain sum paid by cheque and sent to the claimant within a few days. It has adopted this policy, which is similar to that of other health insurance organisations, for sound business reasons.

First, the Commission's experience over many years indicates that for large amounts the use of cheques posted to a valid address acts as a deterrent to claimant fraud. Secondly, cash limits enable the Commission to estimate reliably a branch's cash needs for a day's trading, with advantages both to the Commission's clients and its own operations. Thirdly, the limiting of cash required to be held overnight at branch offices reduces their attractiveness as possible targets for robbery.

The Commission believes its policy is soundly based and prudent, and through this Bill seeks to ensure that the policy is reflected and supported by legislation. At the same time, it is very mindful of its responsibility not to disadvantage claimants in genuine hardship. Branch managers will continue to have the discretion of paying larger benefit claims in cash or by an immediate cheque.

The Bill also facilitates the implementation of a Government commitment, foreshadowed in the 1984 election policy speech, to `extend Medicare to provide reciprocal health care arrangements for countries with which Australia has close ties'. As honourable members may be aware, negotiations to this end have since begun with the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Greece, Yugoslavia, Eire and New Zealand. Reciprocal agreements will allow short term visitors from such countries to Australia access to hospital and medical services for medical conditions requiring urgent treatment, just as Australian visitors to those countries will have similar rights. The agreements will also provide full access for Australian diplomatic and consular staff and their families to the national health schemes in those countries with which agreements are reached. This Bill amends the Health Insurance Act so that diplomatic and consular staff and their families posted to Australia will be entitled to full access to Medicare.

I turn now to those provisions of the Bill which propose changes in relation to the recognition of medical specialists in Australia. By virtue of clauses 29 and 44 the Bill seeks to simplify and streamline the arrangements whereby practitioners are recognised as specialists for the purposes of the Health Insurance Act. At present this is undertaken by ministerial reference to a specialist recognition advisory committee which takes into account an applicant's qualifications, experience and standing in the medical profession, together with the nature of his or her practice.

Under the new arrangements, practitioners will, in general, be automatically recognised as specialists if they are fellows of specified specialist colleges and they have an appropriate qualification obtained by successfully completing a prescribed course of study; or if they are registered as specialists under the laws of the States or Territories. The Minister will retain the right to refer applicants as at present to a specialist recognition advisory committee where automatic recognition does not appear appropriate.

Among other proposed changes are the following: Recognition is to apply on a national basis rather than be restricted to the State or Territory of residence or practice. There is to be a capacity to place a limit on the period of recognition of overseas practitioners temporarily requiring specialist or consultant physician recognition in Australia. The Bill provides that to offset administrative costs a fee-of $30, to be prescribed by regulation-should accompany each application. This fee will produce estimated annual revenue of some $16,500. The more streamlined handling of applications from fellows of specified colleges will result in some small savings. In relation to the $30 fee, I would make the point that recognition as a specialist or consultant physician entitles the practitioner to receive higher rebates for his or her services under Medicare.

The Bill before the House proposes a number of changes to the penalty and disqualification provisions of the Health Insurance Act. These changes represent the most significant amendments contained in the Bill. Honourable members will recall that the present provisions were introduced some three years ago as part of the previous Government's approach to medical benefits fraud-an approach which proved to be unreasonably rigid and insensitive and, in some cases, unnecessarily harsh. The proposed new arrangements address a number of the shortcomings of the existing provisions. Before outlining the major features, let me first reiterate the Government's firm view that it is only a minority of practitioners who abuse the Medicare system and bring dishonour to their profession. I have no doubt that the great majority of practitioners will support these initiatives.

Under the current legislation there is no distinction between the penalties applying to practitioners found guilty of medifraud offences regardless of whether the offence was intentional or the result of reckless or gross careless conduct. No matter the circumstance, disqualification from participation in Medicare applies automatically for three years, where two or more offences are found proven. The Minister does have power to moderate such disqualifications. However, his power is limited only to situations where special circumstances exist, particularly with regard to patient welfare. Thus, moderation cannot be given where the facts otherwise indicate that it would be reasonable to do so.

Another shortcoming relates to the recovery of benefits wrongfully paid. There is currently no specific provision in the Health Insurance Act relating to recovery and, as a matter of equity, the Government has been able to recover only those overpaid benefits paid directly to a practitioner. Recovery from innocent patients is clearly not acceptable. Further, the counselling of practitioners-a particularly effective means of ensuring that doctors fully understand their legal obligations-has been jeopardised by a growing belief that in the absence of privilege for their confidential discussions with medical counsellors prosecution could ensue.
The Bill before the House addresses each of these problems. It proposes a more flexible system for dealing with both wilful and innocent misstatements by practitioners with these major provisions:
The recovery of wrongfully paid benefits from the person responsible for making the false or misleading statement associated with the claim;
The introduction of a summary offence provision for the making of false or misleading statements and of an indictable offence provision for knowingly making false or misleading statements; and

The establishment of a new, independent Medicare participation review committee which is to determine whether the services of offending practitioners should continue to be eligible for Medicare benefits.

The new recovery provisions will apply in all cases where an overpayment has occurred as a result of misitemisation or other misstatement. It will also provide a means of recovery from the practitioner in cases where the practitioner is responsible for the misstatement but the claim has been lodged by the patient. Decisions to recover will be made at a senior level in the Health Insurance Commission. Wherever practicable, recovery will be achieved by negotiation between the Health Insurance Commission and the practitioner concerned, but the Bill does recognise the right to pursue or contest recovery of a debt in civil proceedings. The Bill also provides for interest to be payable on outstanding debts in cases where a practitioner refuses either after official notification of a debt to make restitution within a specified time or defaults on an agreement to repay. Similar provisions will apply where recovery becomes the subject of civil court proceedings.

New offence provisions introduced by the Bill provide that the making of a false or misleading statement will become a statutory, but summary, offence. It will not be necessary for the Crown to prove intent, but a statutory defence is available to a defendant who can establish, on the balance of probabilities, that he or she did not know, and could not reasonably have been expected to know, that either the statement was false or misleading or was capable of being used for obtaining benefits. The Bill also includes a protection against double jeopardy by specifically prohibiting the punishment of a person under more than one provision in the Health Insurance Act in respect of the same offence.

Prosecutions could be commenced in circumstances where it is apparent that the Medicare arrangements are being abused, but not necessarily in a deliberate or intentional manner. Prosecutions under this provision can be instituted within three years of the commission of the alleged offence. This period is necessary to ensure that the offence provision is effective. Similar periods apply elsewhere in Commonwealth legislation. By their nature, offences involving abuse of the Medicare scheme may not be detected until much later, for instance where accounts spanning a considerable period are received. Naturally, as we are dealing with a summary offence, penalties are much less than those provided for in the provision dealing with indictable offences.

I turn now to a new offence provision relating to persons who intentionally make a false or misleading statement which is capable of being used in connection with a claim for Medicare benefits. This is an indictable offence, and the onus will be on the prosecution to prove all elements of the offence beyond reasonable doubt. There is, of course, no time limit for prosecutions for indictable offences. Of course, the Director of Public Prosecutions will be responsible for deciding both whether a prosecution should be commenced and, if so, under which provision.

I refer now to the proposed establishment of the Medicare participation review committees. They are to consider, following a successful prosecution against a practitioner, whether the nature of the offence is such that the practitioner has so abused the position of trust conferred by Medicare that action affecting the practitioner's continuing participation in Medicare is warranted. Such action could entail counselling, reprimand, or disqualification from participating in the Medicare arrangements for a period up to five years. A practitioner will be referred to a committee in all cases where an offence under the Health Insurance Act or a related Crimes Act offence is found proven. The committee is to consider, first, whether in fact any action is warranted. If it decides that action is not warranted, the matter will be immediately disposed of. Where the committee decides that some action may be warranted, the practitioner will be able to appear before the committee and be represented. There is provision for partial or full disqualification. A partial disqualification would mean that a service, or perhaps some services, when rendered by the practitioner would be ineligible for Medicare benefits. A committee could consider a partial disqualification appropriate where, for example, a practitioner has abused the system in respect of one item in the schedule or where full disqualification may seriously disadvantage a particular community.

The new arrangements provide for the issue of guidelines by the Minister to assist committees in the performance of their functions and ensure a consistent and even-handed approach. To this end, the guidelines are being prepared in consultation with the professional bodies. The guidelines will be subject to the normal parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance provisions. A right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from decisions by the committee will exist. It is proposed that the committees comprise:
An independent chairperson with legal qualifications and considerable legal experience;
a person, nominated by the Minister, who is a member of the same profession as the practitioner before the committee; and
in cases involving medical practitioners, a person nominated by the Australian Medical Association; or
in cases involving non-medical practitioners, a nominee of the relevant professional association.

Relevant professional associations will be consulted when considering the appointment of chairpersons. As honourable members can see, the committee will be an independent body which well be competent to determine, on the basis of evidence put before it, the matters referred to it.

This Bill also provides for the extension of statutory privilege for information obtained by medical counsellors during interviews with practitioners. As I said earlier, there has been a growing belief that confidential discussions with counsellors can lead to prosecution of practitioners. This amendment, which will cover both oral statements made in interviews and any written records of them, will protect the frank and free discussion so necessary if the objectives and benefits of counselling are to be achieved. I should perhaps point out that counselling is intended to be quite separate from the investigation of persons suspected of committing offences, and that the extension of privilege will enhance, rather than detract from, the effective administration of Medicare.

Another aspect of the current legislation addressed by the Bill is that it is silent on who is to fill in the practitioner's account or receipt. It is clearly not appropriate for it to be the responsibility of patients. Hence, the Bill amends the Health Insurance Act to provide that Medicare benefits are payable only where a practitioner or his staff includes the prescribed information on accounts. In summary, the information-to be prescribed by regulation-that will be necessary for the payment of Medicare benefits will be:
Identification of the practitioner by name and either practice address or provider number;
Sufficient information to enable identification of the patient; and
A description of the services provided sufficient to identify the Medicare benefits schedule item relating to those services.

The new provisions will enable the Health Insurance Commission to have sufficient information to pay benefits. The less prescriptive requirements should meet with the approval of practitioners. It will be a matter for their own convenience if they continue to include item numbers with short descriptions of the services, as many do at present.

Honourable members will note that the transitional arrangements include a provision enabling practitioners who are currently disqualified to apply to the Medicare participation review committee for a review of their disqualification terms. The committee will have the power to moderate such terms-It will not have power to increase them.

Perhaps I should emphasise that the Bill was drafted before the recent report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts into pathology was released. This report is now under consideration by the Government. It is possible, therefore, that further amendments of the offence provisions of the Health Insurance Act will need to be made following full consideration of the report.

The measures I have outlined are the product of an extensive process of consultation with those professional associations whose members are most affected by them. The new arrangements have been endorsed by the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Optometrical Association and the Australian Dental Association. I believe the new scheme will provide a fair and effective framework for dealing with future cases of abuse and misuse of Medicare. As such they are a major advance on the present legislation, which has done little to curb such abuse and misuse while at the same time antagonising the great majority of practitioners who are honourable and honest in the practice of their professions.

I turn now to clauses 57 to 66 of the Bill which deal with another significant Government initiative-the introduction of a national identification system using cards to be known as Australia Cards. As honourable members will be aware, the system is an important part of the Government's planned reform of the Australian taxation system, as outlined to the House by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his statement of 19 September 1985. As the Treasurer indicated on that occasion, the Australia Card is a weapon in combating tax evasion and reducing welfare fraud in the community.

Because of its acknowledged technical expertise, it is intended that the Health Insurance Commission, which administers Medicare and Medibank Private, will, under substantive legislation to be brought forward in the autumn sitting next year, be given responsibility for administering the identification system. In the meantime, in order to enable the Commission to undertake planning and development work necessary for the Australia card system, an amendment is required to the Health Insurance Commission Act. That is the purpose of this part of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. Various methods of authorisation were considered but none of them provided a completely satisfactory legal framework within which the Commission could carry out its planning and development role. It was important, therefore, to prepare this enabling legislation in advance of the substantive legislation.

The Government intends that the national identification system become fully operational from July 1989. As a first step, it is planned that the issuing of Australia Cards begin in March 1987. Thus the Commission has a period of 18 months from now to undertake the necessary planning and development for the card issue.

I emphasise that this enabling legislation allows for no more than planning and development work. For this reason, a sunset clause has been included which means that the legislation will cease to have effect after December 1986 unless substantive legislation providing for the establishment and administration of the Australia Card program has been enacted before that date.

In accordance with the specific provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act which require a system of cost apportionment to be applied when determining the assets and breakdown of expenditure by the Commission with respect to its various functions, other machinery changes to the Act have also been included. These will ensure that correct and proper financial accounting takes place within the organisation. In support of this part of the Bill, let me simply say that the Government is convinced that the system is crucial to ensure that everyone in the community contributes fairly towards the cost of providing government services and that no individuals or groups take more than their fair entitlement out of the community purse. The cost to the Government for the planning and development by the Health Insurance Commission of the Australia Card identification system is estimated to be $3.5m during 1985-86. The amount of expenditure in subsequent years is dependent upon the enactment and timing of substantive legislation providing for the Australia Card identification system. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are considering the appropriations which relate to the Department of Social Security. The amounts involved in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86 are substantial. Unfortunately, the time available to me does not permit a detailed examination of the entire range of subjects covered. The past 12 months have been significant for the Department. The Government has chosen to divide the responsibilities and create a new department known as the Department of Community Services. Part of the existing responsibilities have been left with the Department of Social Security.

SPEECH.PARA: During the year the Auditor-General conducted a review of the Department of Social Security's activities. Some of the comments made in the Auditor-General's report have a bearing on the appropriations we are considering today. The Auditor-General undertakes periodic reviews of departmental activity. As part of those reviews he undertakes an audit of the administrative procedures of departmental offices. In his latest report some of the comments he made concerning departmental procedures are worthy of consideration and hopefully review by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in the coming 12 months. At five of the regional offices of the Department-to be fair, there are 209 or 210 regional offices-the Auditor-General undertook a review of the procedures adopted by the Department to establish the identity of applicants. On the basis of that review he concluded:
These omissions represented an approximate 10 per cent failure rate in the application of or evidencing of adequate identification procedures.
He considered that to be unsatisfactory. The Auditor-General also undertook reviews at some regional offices visited in New South Wales and one in Western Australia. His report stated:

. . . it was noted that selective intensive reviews were not being performed for considerable periods. Regional management attributed this position to shortages of field officer resources due to introduction of the assets test and other priorities.

This was, of course, a political decision on the part of the Government to allocate departmental resources to the implementation of the assets test. At a later time today I will make some comments about the implementation of the assets test and the delays encountered in certain aspects of the administrative procedures. I am sure that other speakers in this debate will also comment on the implementation of the assets test and its implications for members of our community. The Auditor-General-these items to which I am referring are more illustrative than anything else-also checked on the procedures adopted by the Department in the verification of employers' reports. The Auditor-General said:

Cases detected at regional offices visited where either employers' reports seeking information in regard to an applicant's date of cessation of work or income details were either not sent or not followed up represented a failure rate of almost 20 per cent of cases selected.
He then stated:
This demonstrates serious breakdown in a key contol.
As part of the audit conclusion, the Auditor-General stated:

The findings outlined above reflect a high incidence of breakdowns within the system and are of concern to Audit particularly as irregularities in the operation of key controls have been the subject of recurrent previous criticism. These latest results, the increasing number of fraudulent cases being reported, and the continuing rise in overpayments, indicate the need for greater departmental activity in monitoring of the area. It is recognised that recent initiatives taken by the Department including those in relation to proof of identity have not yet been evaluated and the impact of these and other initiatives in progress such as in measures for quality assurance will be reviewed in subsequent audits.

There has been considerable Press comment as a result of the Auditor-General's report. Extrapolations were made from the findings contained in that report that the degree of overpayment could be as high as some $350m. I would be the first to acknowledge, not simply because the Minister is in the House but simply because I have some respect for the mathematical accuracy, that those extrapolations could be quite dubious. However, I think the principle that is covered in that report is very important. There is an absolute need to ensure the integrity of the payments system for the Department of Social Security, to the extent that there are failures in the system because the Government, for reasons of its political priorities, decided to concentrate on the assets test is alarming.

The Australian people cannot be expected to accept the explanation given by the Minister that the overpayment rate represented in the order of a one per cent failure rate in the system of total payment. The order of magnitude of these overpayments, as suggested by those extrapolations-again I say that they could have a dubious statistical base-is such that I believe that the Minister has a responsibility to the Australian people to conduct a thorough review of procedures adopted by the Department to ensure that there is minimisation of overpayment and the system is of high integrity. It is incumbent upon him, as Minister, to ensure that the funds of the Australian taxpayer-scarce resources-are not wasted.

In making my introductory remarks I said that part of this problem arose from the assets test and the allocation to the implementation of the assets test of staff from the Department who would normally be involved in review procedures. Obviously, notwithstanding that this reallocation of staff resources has been disruptive on the normal procedures of the Department, enough staff has not been allocated to the administrative procedures of the assets test.

We learn from information provided in another place that the approximate delay for appeal procedures for assets test review cases is some 19 weeks and that officers of the Department believe that the average time taken to process a request for a review under the assets test is some six months. The Opposition believes that this is a totally unsatisfactory situation. People who are potentially in difficult financial circumstances, because they do not perhaps fit the hardship provisions announced by the Government which cater for people who have been affected by the assets test, cannot be expected to wait six months for a review of the impact of the assets test on them to be undertaken.

I know that the Minister will probably respond and say that there is a fast lane for people who are in obvious circumstances of hardship, but this again is not satisfactory. It is very difficult to define exactly what hardship is. I do not believe it is possible to draw up a set of guidelines that will take account of the real circumstances that people find themselves in. Unforeseen financial burdens can arise almost overnight and change a person's circumstances after he has been assessed by departmental officers as not being a genuine hardship case.

Another matter to which I would like to address a few remarks is the implementation of Stratplan. Stratplan is the Department's upgrading of computer facilities to provide a networking operation of information on a real time basis through regional offices throughout Australia. When this proposal was introduced it was suggested that it would result in not only better service but also considerable cost and staff savings. It concerns me that there has been what appears to be a cost overrun in the implementation of Stratplan, that it is not on schedule and that staff savings will not be realised. If the Minister is in a position to provide detailed comment on the cost of implementing Stratplan hardware, the necessary changes to departmental furniture and fittings and other costs that have arisen out of industrial relations matters, I am sure that members of this Parliament would be particularly interested. It seems curious to me that the spending of some $250m on implementing a very modern and technologically sophisticated computer system will not result in any direct staff saving. It is incumbent upon the Minister to explain the exact impact of Stratplan on the costs of the Department and its future operating responsibilities.

Prior to the commencement of this debate the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) introduced a Bill which, in effect, will provide for the Australia Card. The Australia Card is an extremely controversial proposal introduced the other day by the Government as part of its tax package. Obviously it will have an impact on the collection of tax revenue throughout this country. I do not have the time to discuss its implications in full, but I warn honourable members that they are in many cases bad news for veterans.

Furthermore, it is inconsistent for this Government to argue that paying out pensions that range from 40c per week to $4.50 per week for wives and from 14c to $1.38 for children is not worth while when the benefits of its own recent tax cuts do not amount to much more and in some cases not as much. The 40-year rule is unjust and unnecessary. It is based on an arbitrary deadline which in itself is debatable. The rule says that for widows whose husbands die more than forty years after war service, the Repatriation Commission will have to be `reasonably satisfied that the material before it raises a reasonable hypothesis that the claimed death or incapacity was war caused' before it will grant a pension. In cases where the cause or aetiology of a disease is unknown and cause of death cannot be determined, a pension will not be granted. It is tough luck for those wives whose husbands die a day, a week or a year after the deadline. Had their men passed away a day or a year prior to the cut-off date, their claim would be simple. Widows will miss out because of Senator Gietzelt's ridiculous and arbitrary 40-year rule.

The Minister has said that very few conditions would take longer than 40 years to manifest themselves. The West Australian Law Reform Commission said that `long stop' approaches are wrong because some diseases, such as asbestosis, need at least 40 years coverage. If these veterans will no longer be entitled to increased compensation as their dis- ability worsens, who will compensate them for a continued but also worsening quality of life in their retirement? Certainly it will not be this Government.

We are committed, and were committed many years ago, to compensate veterans when their quality of life worsens with age; that is, where veterans sustained injury or disability in the first instance as a result of war service. Many Australian pensioners enjoy a healthy retirement. Unfortunately, that situation will not apply to some veterans in our community, who will be deprived after the age of 65 of making a claim for a T and PI pension.
