TALK.START.PARA: —Preparing and implementing budgets is not a challenge faced only by those in the political, bureaucratic or business sectors of our community. Budgeting is an exercise undertaken on a continuing basis, albeit with varying degrees of expertise, enthusiasm and success, by every individual, group or organisation in receipt of an income. In simplest terms, it is the allocation of available resources to cover necessary expenditures.

SPEECH.PARA: When dealing with sensitive areas such as social security and health, it may be argued that available resources are not sufficient to cover necessary expenditures. If and when this occurs a government has two alternatives-to increase the available resources or to review or redefine what constitutes necessary expenditures. A responsible government should always thoroughly examine the latter option before contemplating the former. A prudent budget will allow for past, present and future needs and expenses. It will provide for known liabilities and unexpected contingencies. It is of little consequence whether a budget strategy is designed to cater for the financial situation which currently exists within a home, a business or a nation. The same basic challenges confront those involved in the budgetary process and the same basic principles of sound economic judgment, management and administration must be applied if, in the final analysis, the books are to balance.

There are several significant factors that provide unique advantages for those who are responsible for planning a budget on behalf of government compared with corporate or home budget strategists. Not the least of these is the fact that governments have the opportunity to decide how much they are going to spend and then to set about raising the required amount through borrowings, taxes and other imposts. In the 1985-86 Budget, an increase of 8.4 per cent in total spending has been funded by an increase of 12.6 percent in total revenue. Welfare benefits alone will cost taxpayers an additional $1.244 billion this financial year. The rest of us, including most of the business community, must tackle the problem from a quite different angle. Our budget deliberations and decisions are influenced by having to tailor our expenditure to suit a known, usually rather inflexible, income figure. Whilst we have to adjust our spending according to our anticipated income, the Government enjoys the luxury and flexibility of being able to adjust its income to suit its anticipated spending.

As a consequence of this state of affairs-fortunate for the Government but unfortunate for the taxpayer, there is a tendency for the Government to be rather more extravagant and generous than is either necessary or justifiable. This applies not only when assessing the real needs and reasonable requirements of those eligible to receive assistance and/or benefits, but also in regard to the costs associated with administering their provision. It is a shame that the world's best Treasurer does not heed Mr Micawber's wise though simple advice to David Copperfield when he said:
Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure nineteen pounds nineteen and sixpence-result happiness. Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure twenty pounds and sixpence-result misery.

Mr Micawber's recipe for budgetary success was based, quite correctly, on restraint as the major ingredient. It is apparent that restraint is not a popular word in the vocabulary or budget strategy of the Hawke Government, especially in some of the areas of spending that we are considering in this debate. It is an indisputable and somewhat sobering fact that this socialist Government is the biggest spending Australian government-apart from the Whitlam extravaganza-in over three decades.

Too little account is being taken of the long term results, ultimately the budgetary consequences, of policies designed to win short term approval from certain sections of, and powerful lobby groups within, the electorate. The 1985 Budget, presented in a novel three-part format-which reflects the fact that the Government knows that it falls into the bad news category and so has adopted the `breaking it to them gently' technique-certainly lends support to the theory that disasters come in threes.

Despite the Government's attempts to convince us that things have never been so good, it is obvious that the reverse is the case. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seem to believe that, if they keep saying that everything in the garden is rosy, we will eventually accept their protestations and propaganda as being the truth, that we will ignore the reality and accept the myth. Of course, we cannot and we will not.

It is not possible to ignore the fact that this country is now so far into the red-honourable members may interpret that in any way they wish-that the national public sector debt is now equivalent to an amount of more than $12,000 for every employed person. Provision for the repayment of interest on the Federal government debt now exceeds Budget provisions for spending on education, health and defence. It rivals Federal outlays to State and local governments. Total government spending now accounts for almost half of our national income. The average Australian wage earner now works for almost six months of each year to pay the bills of government.

Some of the major factors contributing to the ever increasing enormity of these bills of government, as previously noted, are the costs involved in providing community, social security and health services. Already, personal benefits payments account for over one-third of all Budget outlays. Over the past 10 years there has been a 20-fold increase in the number of people receiving the unemployment benefit, and a five-fold increase in the number of recipients of the supporting parents benefit. The over 50 per cent increase in the number of invalid pensioners and the almost 35 per cent increase in the number of age pensioners seem almost modest in comparison.

Faced with these figures, one would hope that the Government would attempt to redress the welfare payments spiral by helping people to help themselves. But, no-those who endeavour to build up a nest egg are portrayed as wealthy parasites who rip the system off. A responsible and thrifty approach to providing for the future is, under this socialist Government, simply not acceptable. Self-reliance is not regarded as a virtue, and the acquiring of assets has, in effect, become an offence punishable by law.

On the one hand, the Government is prepared, even though it cannot really afford to do so, to maintain one of the most easily `tapped into' welfare payment systems in the world. On the other hand, it imposes penalties for those who are effectively reducing the long term burden on the long-suffering taxpayers by attempting to create some modicum of financial independence and security for themselves and their families-a sort of `the more you do for your country, the less your country will do for you' mentality.

Nowhere is this appalling state of affairs more graphically illustrated than in the case of the 13,272 war veterans who have had their pensions cancelled or reduced in the last financial year because of the assets test. Additionally there is growing evidence to show that very few pensions have been restored under the hardship provisions. So much for the promises of a Prime Minister who has a growing reputation for erring on the side of generosity. Under the Hawke Government this is how a grateful nation says thank you. There is more of the same in store under the Veterans' Entitlements-or rather lack of entitlements-Bill. People who are deserving of a little government generosity are denied it whilst those who have done little to deserve it are ready, willing and able to exploit the system to the full.

Let us briefly consider the health services cost spiral. Spending on health services is up by almost 10 per cent. Medical benefit payments under Medicare are up by 11.4 per cent. These costs are escalating more rapidly than revenue from the levy. Benefits are estimated to increase by $255.6m compared with the levy revenue increase of only $130m more than last year. These expenditure estimates may prove far too low once the impact of the recent severe influenza epidemic has been properly and fully taken into account. Sooner or later-certainly sooner than most people would care to think about-this country will have to face the problem of having too many people lining up in the receiving queue and far too few in the contributing queue.

The profile reveals that the top 25 pathology companies in Australia perform an enormous percentage of the pathology work done. In fact, the top seven companies perform a very significant proportion of the pathology services performed in this country.

In the breakdown of material available from the charts provided in the Committee's report we were able to see the number of pathology services per patient. That is very useful information because a comparison of the various pathology companies enables us to see where there is a wide variation in the number of pathology services provided per patient. That may not necessarily be bad. However, it does alert investigators to the possible need for investigation in that area. Also the profile shows the Medicare benefit paid out per patient.

When honourable members look at this report they will be amazed to see the cost to the taxpayer in the pathology area. When one looks at the pathology groups in the top 25 for the March quarter 1985, the Medicare benefit per patient who receives pathology services varies from about $66 to $114. That is an extraordinary amount of money. Governments cannot just keep providing an open cheque in this area of pathology services, so it is critical that the Government investigate thoroughly the areas where there is a likelihood of fraud and overservicing.

Just to reiterate the point that I made earlier, the Committee does not say that the large pathology services are practising fraud in this area or are overservicing. We are not saying that at all. Big does not necessarily mean bad, but what the report does is alert the community to the high concentration of ownership that exists in this industry and it also gives us the opportunity to compare the costs per service of the various pathology companies. I recommend a detailed analysis of that report to honourable members. I am very pleased to see now that the media is taking up this whole general area of pathology fraud. I noticed in the National Times this week a very good analysis of it and I understand that the Sydney Morning Herald is doing further work on it. It is unfortunate that the main focus of the debate on this issue has been on two pages related to a Dr X, but I recommend the total report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to dwell on the estimates in relation to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which are of critical importance. This whole policy area has been the subject of a good deal of controversy throughout the calendar year 1985. In fact, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86 provides estimates of $423,836,000 for administration, $104,346,000 for the Defence Services Homes Corporation and, more significantly, $8,220,000 for the Australian War Memorial which I freely acknowledge is an increase of $1.5m. I will be visiting the Australian War Memorial next Monday. I look forward to that. Earlier this week I had information made available to me and therefore had good and proper reason to say that the War Memorial has been haemmorhaging badly at the specialised middle management level. The spate of resignations at the War Memorial far exceeds what might be regarded as reasonable turnover. They are not resigning for essentially personal reasons, as has been suggested elsewhere, but for other reasons. There is a problem or there are problems there. I do not particularly point the bone at anybody, but I stick to my guns in respect of the comments I made on the Australian War Memorial and I will further pursue that matter down the track.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Veterans' Affairs estimates reflect changes which were brought about associated with the mini-Budget earlier this year which resulted in a spate of cutbacks introduced in relation to veterans' entitlements. This House next Thursday or thereabouts is scheduled to have the revised Veterans' Entitlements Bill presented to the Parliament. We await that with a great deal of interest. The coalition will study that Bill clause by clause to determine its final attitude on a Bill which may well be changed from the exposure draft. Therefore, it does deserve a clause by clause study in the interests of all the veterans in Australia. At the moment those veterans are very concerned over a number of the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill and some of the unjust and arbitrary sections of it.

I am very pleased to support the strategy of the Returned Services League of Australia and veterans' organisations. I have taken on board submissions from those organisations. Since being appointed shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in recent weeks I have travelled to Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Penola in South Australia and elsewhere to ensure that I have the latest information from veterans' organisations in respect of their reactions to the draft Veterans' Entitlements Bill. I serve notice that the coalition will be taking a responsible but comprehensive approach to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill because in fact it does reflect, and its provisions certainly will reflect, on the estimates of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. More particularly, it will reflect on that which is provided for those who served their country in time of war. Our commitment is a responsible absolute commitment to those who served their country in time of war.

Turning to two special areas which are reflected in the estimates before the Committee, I would like to highlight the changes that have taken place in travel allowances flowing from administrative decisions partly announced in the mini-Budget and applicable since 1 July last. I refer to the decision by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), presumably, to almost halve the travel allowance for veterans going for medical treatment, medical referral or examination who use their private vehicle. The rates varied from 18c to 27c and have been reduced to a flat rate of 11.16c per kilometre. The interesting thing about that rate is the fact that the comparable Public Service travel rate for smaller-sized vehicles is some 23.3c per kilometre-double what the Department is prepared to pay a veteran encouraged to use his own car to avoid more costly methods of travel. It is not good enough that, at the same time as reducing the travel amount per kilometre, the Department has imposed a day allowance at a flat rate of $40. That is again another substantial reduction at a time when costs for meals and travel are continuing to increase rapidly. This will impact especially where there are areas of no public transport and has the danger of making it especially difficult for veterans in gaining adequate transport arrangements associated with these cut-backs in travel allowances for veterans.

I contend very strongly that the changes on travel allowance are unfair and are arbitrary in their across-the-board approach. I recognise that there were some excesses in the previous travel allowance system which had to be addressed by the Government. However, by adopting the across-the-board approach to veterans right across Australia-whether they be in the electorate of Cowper, where the honourable member (Mr Nehl) has assiduously pursued this matter as well as the assets test, or in other electorates-these cut-backs will have a very harsh application on veterans who have served their country in time of war.

I would like now to deal with the changed arrangements for dental treatment which applies to veterans. I refer to two decisions. The first decision imposes a $300 maximum limit for four categories of dental treatment. On top of that, it changes arrangements in terms of providing direct access to prostheses. This is to apply in the three States already registered and to additional States where registration legislation is in train. There is considerable concern in the veterans' community that the upshot of all those changes in the area of dental treatment is that the veteran is receiving second class arrangements in terms of dental health care at a time when many of them are reaching an age where that is becoming more and more a critical issue for them. Veterans particularly resent the arbitrary $300 limit on four categories of dental treatment which has been applied across-the-board without recognition of the special arrangements that could have been arrived at to take account of the abuses and excesses that may have been occurring. Instead, we have the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs adopting this sledgehammer across-the-board approach with the resultant deterioration in the service which is available to veterans.

It is not possible in the time available to track through the many other detailed aspects of the estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs other than to say that last financial year, as determined in evidence given to the Senate Estimates Committee, 13,272 veterans had their pensions slashed, reduced or cancelled by Labor's assets test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for his courtesy in enabling me to participate in this debate. It will come as no surprise to honourable members that in a debate on social welfare I wish once again to raise in this House the in- iquitous assets test. I pay tribute to the Minister for the changes he made earlier this year in the hardship allowances. They have been helpful to many pensioners in Cowper and throughout Australia. But I say to the Minister clearly and unequivocally that those changes have not gone far enough. In fact, they have not addressed what I believe to be the most significant problem within the assets test. I refer to the question of curtilage, the restricted area around family homes on farm properties. People throughout Cowper and throughout Australia are being unfairly discriminated against because of the curtilage provision. Those who have farms comprising perhaps 150 or 200 acres-farms where they have lived all their lives, where they have married, where their children have been born, where their husband or wife may have died and been buried-are being forced either to do without the pension entirely or in part, or to sell and move off their farms. I submit in all sincerity that this is unfair and unjust.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to the Minister that the Government should take a very close look at the curtilage provision. Take, for instance, a farm property valued at $250,000 with a curtilage area of 2 1/2 hectares which is valued at $50,000 and the rest of the farm valued at $200,000. In such a case, the person concerned loses the pension entirely. But another pensioner who lives in Sydney, Port Macquarie or Coffs Harbour who has the same total asset value of $250,000, comprising $50,000 in liquid assets and $200,000 in a house, will keep the pension entirely. However, the rural pensioner who has the same value of assets loses the pension. This is totally unjust and discriminates against rural pensioners. I take this opportunity to plead with the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I have no false pride on this. I believe it is so vital to the elderly people of Australia that, if necessary, I will go down on my knees to seek special consideration to this problem of curtilage. It is vitally important and I thank the House for its courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank honourable members who have contributed to this debate. In broad terms, it is interesting that there are two main thrusts in this debate. On the one hand we have the people who believe that the measures foreshadowed in the Veterans' Entitlements Bill that has been available for scrutiny and subject to review are far too harsh and tough. Furthermore, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) again said that the assets test is far too tough. On the other hand, a number of speakers in this debate said that the Government must be very much tougher indeed. The honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) articulated this view very clearly, and I understand that his view is widely shared within the Opposition. He said that there is an economist by the name Micawber who suggests that the Government should adopt a Micawber-like, book-balancing, accountant's approach to expenditure. He talked of the misery endured by the individual who spends one sixpence over income.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Casey suggested that expenditure on social security had gone mad. I think he said that half the Budget was going into the area of social security, that it was increasing rapidly and getting hopelessly out of control, and that therefore the Government needed to take a very much tougher approach. The honourable member for Casey does not know what he is talking about. If one looks at the trend in social security expenditure in recent years, one finds that, expressed as a percentage of total outlays, expenditure on social security and welfare has been declining since we were in government. It peaked in 1983-84 but has declined since. Over time one could say that roughly social security and social welfare as a percentage of total outlays has been relatively stable-around 27 to 29 per cent, peaking in 1983-84 for a reason I shall return to. If we look at social expenditure as a percentage of gross domestic product, we see again that the pattern is not one of great increase, but rather of a peak again in 1983-84 and then a decline from 8.8 per cent in 1983-84 to 8.2 per cent in 1985-86.

There is a very good reason for that and it is important, if a more radical and more ideological approach is to be adopted by the Opposition, that its members think through what they are saying. It is all very well for the honourable member for Casey to make a series of generalised statements about the Micawber approach to economics that will be adopted by the coalition parties whenever they return to government and on the other hand to take the view that the Government should not touch veterans.

Let us examine the reasons for increases in social security expenditure. As I said, expenditure peaked in 1983-84. Interestingly enough, if one goes back one finds that as at September 1983 unemployment had reached 617,000. Those people were unemployment beneficiaries. If we come to 27 September this year, we see from the most recent figures that the number of people on benefits totalled 534,000. Over that period this Government has done what the previous Government did not do. It has reversed the unemployment trend, which means that the Government has achieved significant savings in social security expenditure. These significant savings reflect the fact that the Government is getting on top of the problem of unemployment, or at least is making some progress. Let us look back over a decade at what has been occurring in social security. It is important for Opposition members, if they are to become more ideological and to take the view that what is needed is a radical change, to look at what has occurred historically. Over the last 10 years unemployment has taken a huge whack of social security expenditure-from something like $500m in 1975 to more than $3 billion in the recent financial year. There has been that massive increase in social security expenditure.

It will be established to anyone who seriously looks at the figures that overall expenditure has been relatively stable in recent years as a percentage of the Budget and gross domestic product. There has been a redistribution of the social welfare dollar over the 10 years I am referring to since Labor went out of government in 1975. More and more money has had to go to pay people who are not in the work force. In 1975 a very high percentage of the poor were the aged. If one examines the current situation in 1985, one finds that the aged are not generally poor, unless they are renting. The people who are poor in the aged population are not the people affected by the assets test. I know there can be emotional arguments on this matter, but essentially those who are poor in the aged population are renters. One need only look at the level of rents in any of the major cities of Australia to appreciate that it is impossible for people to live in private rental accommodation and survive if all they have is a pension and perhaps a supplementary rent allowance. One has to acknowledge that there is real poverty in this area.

In terms of the overall population, in my view, new groups of people have become extremely poor. Those people are led by the unemployed, who have received a level of benefit which, generally speaking, is much less than the pension. The age pension has been indexed and has kept up with inflation. People in receipt of the unemployment benefit have not received that kind of assistance.

It is important to note that, whatever one might say was good about the Fraser Government, there was a terrible prejudice in that Government against the unemployed. The graph shows that there was a massive growth in the number of unemployed during the Fraser years. The Fraser Government had a terrible prejudice against those people whom it believed did not deserve real levels of assistance. For example, the single adult rate of unemployment benefit under the Fraser Government declined by 7.5 per cent and the junior rate, the benefit received by the young unemployed, decreased by 63 per cent. So one group of people got a very bad deal under the previous Government, and I do not think that anyone on the other side of the chamber could honestly disagree with that proposition. A person who was unemployed and in private rental accommodation during the Fraser years would have been in great difficulty.

Another group that grew as a percentage of total beneficiaries during the Fraser years was the group of people who were affected by unemployment because of other factors. The only people who were able to get into the very tight labour market were people with skills and training, the young, the vigorous and so on. Let us consider the other groups which grew. The two major categories were invalid pensioners, who are very often people with some disability which makes it hard for them to get into the labour force, and supporting parents. What did the Fraser Government do for supporting parents, many with very young children, who could not get out into the work force? During the Fraser years the mother's guardian's allowance decreased by 10.4 per cent. The Fraser Government did not index family allowances-that was a transfer across the Budget. The additional children's allowance decreased by nearly 28 per cent during the Fraser years.

Everyone knows that, apart from private rental accommodation, the other indicator of poverty in respect of pensioners and beneficiaries is costs associated with children, which are so great. One can only imagine how people survive on the benefits they receive. How would the honourable member for Cowper survive on those benefits if he had to live with one or two children in a crowded flat in an inner city or western suburbs area of Sydney, where rents might be $60 or $70 a week? How would he survive on the single rate pension, at about $90, with an additional pension and benefit of perhaps $10 under Fraser, and perhaps a few more dollars by way of the mother's guardian's allowance, and paying the level of rent I have mentioned, as well as coping with all the other pressures that have to be faced? (Quorum formed) Under the Fraser Government we had declining levels of payments to the very poor. This Government has sought to target any increase that have been available, not to beneficiaries in a general sense but to the people who we believe are very poor. I think it is very sad that the shadow Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), should come into the chamber and, in the debate on the social security budget, not say a single word about the problem of poverty in the Australian community. We cannot have 500,000 to 600,000 people unemployed, as we have, or the social conditions that have existed in this country over the past 10 years, and not have a great deal of poverty. The problem faced by governments, using the tight fiscal approach that this Government has adopted, is how to do something about poverty, which I believe most Australians consider to be anathema and something which ought not to exist in this country.

The honourable member for Richmond expressed great concern about the integrity of the social welfare payment system. I think he would have been much better served if he had spent a little time dealing with the integrity of the Opposition spokesman on Public Service matters, who extrapolated some figures out of the Auditor-General's report and came up with the massive figure of $350m of supposed overpayments which have been lost to revenue. The claim bears no relation to reality. It was based on the activities of five offices before we had improved the identity checks. He made a big thing about that. The honourable member for Richmond referred to this and said: `Well, of course, his mathematics are not all that good'. Nevertheless, he reinforced the figure of $350m. No reference was made to the fact that the procedures had been sorted out in respect of the five offices that were the subject of study in regard to identity checks. Frankly, he has a long way to go in that area.

The honourable member for Richmond referred also to the problems we have had with the assets test. I acknowledge that there have been problems associated with this test, but ultimately, when we get right down to it, the problem for conservatives is that they build a class bias into every argument. In the final analysis, they will come in here and rant and rave, but we know ultimately whom they are seeking to look after. That is what they are not prepared to face up to and that is why Mr Valder had to try to put a bit of steel into their backs. There is not much steel left in the conservative parties, but Mr Valder at least, one would have thought, holds the official view in relation to the assets test. There are some concerns about the Stratplan which I think were dealt with during the hearings of a Senate Estimates committee. We will come back to the question of identification cards when the relevant legislation is ultimately introduced.

It has been good to hear the discussion that has taken place. However, I believe that poverty represents, if not the most important, then one of the most important issues that face this country. Governments have been singularly unsuccessful in reducing poverty. I hope that this Government is at least targeting what it is doing in the right areas and moving in the right direction. I hope that as a result of the policies adopted by this Government, not just in this Budget but looking at three or four Budgets together, this country will move towards a much fairer society. I believe that that is what we, as a Labor government, ought to be about.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Progress reported.
