TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the Government's decision requiring the United States of America to reduce the number of its naval visits to Western Australian ports. In view of the increasing build-up of the Soviet Navy in the Indian Ocean, the Pacific Ocean and the South China Sea, and the deteriorating defence relationship between the United States and New Zealand and its serious implications for ANZUS, how can this decision be justified?
—Don't tell me you have lost that file as well!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not lost that file. I can assure the Leader of the Opposition that I have lost no relevant file on this matter. It is of interest to me that at last the Leader of the Opposition has addressed himself to the area of our international relationships and, in particular, he has done it in regard to our relationships with the United States. I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition is the last person who has any credibility when it comes to talking about relations with the United States. I remind him of something which he would rather forget. On 5 October 1984, just over a year ago, he was asked about the President of the United States. This is what the Leader of the Opposition had to say about the President of the United States, Ronald Reagan:

ANSWER.PARA: There is still too much of the actor in him to really convince me.

That was the Leader of the Opposition, the alternative Prime Minister of this country, speaking about the United States President. This shows the quality of a man who purports to lecture me. If I have something to say about the position of this country on a fundamental issue, such as racial equality in South Africa, which indicates that I have a difference of opinion with the Prime Minister of Britain-as I do-he lectures me and says: `Why should you be getting up and saying things like that about the head of another state?'. He is the very same man who, in respect of the President of the United States, says: `There is too much of the actor in him to really convince me'. What sort of basis does this give the Leader of the Opposition to address himself to this matter?

As to the factual situation about our relationship with the United States and the judgment that is made by the President of the United States, who was derided by the Leader of the Opposition, I remind the House of what the President of the United States has recently said about his assessment of the relationship between the United States and Australia which takes into account fully the range of decisions and attitudes expressed by this Government. This is what the President of the United States said recently when the new Australian Ambassador to the United States presented his credentials to him:

I have taken note of your remarks and want you to know that I and others of the American Government share your appreciation of the close and enduring relations between our two nations. Your Prime Minister has publicly stated that our relations have never been closer and I believe that is truly the case.

I say to the Leader of the Opposition: `There you have a judgment out of the mouth of the President of the United States, the man who is able to make a judgment and assessment of the relationship between our two countries on the basis of all the decisions that have been taken by this Government in regard to not only the particular issue he raises but also a whole range of policy issues which determine the nature of our relationship'. It is a judgment of the President of the United States and not that of this myopic creature whose position is to abuse the President of the United States. The judgment of the President of the United States is that, looking back over the period when the Opposition had the opportunity of conducting this relationship and establishing a position between Australia and the United States, the relationship established by this Government with the United States is better than it has ever been. In those circumstances for the Leader of the Opposition to pretend that any decision that has been taken by this Government represents some diminution or hurt to the relationship is revealed for the hypocritical nonsense that it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Attorney-General by saying that he would agree with me that far more money is being fleeced from our community by the end of a ball point pen than at the end of a smoking .38.
—What about government advertising?
—Would my good friend like to debate it?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will not find me so tolerant this afternoon.

—Given the appalling escalation of pin-stripe crime, does the Attorney-General see an urgent need to reappraise the structures by which that sort of crime is dealt with in the legal system? Will he take steps to set up a separate commercial division within the Federal Court of Australia to deal with extremely complicated commercial crime? Will he consider that such courts comprise specialist judges and expert assessors in prosecutions for breaches of commercial law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hawker raises a very important matter in terms of the modern problems facing all administrations throughout the world in bringing what is called white collar crime-or, as my colleague says, pin stripe crime-to justice. The interesting thing about the law-it is not always recognised-is that it is continually reforming itself to meet the challenges of society, particularly in the area of crime. A recent conference in Milan which Australians attended-I was able to lead the delegation-passed a unanimous resolution indicating that organised crime, and that relates to the matters to which the honourable gentleman referred, is on the increase. It is no longer confined to national borders; it is international; it is very sophisticated; it involves the transfer of substantial sums of money and the criminals having very expert knowledge of commercial transactions and how to move volumes of money across the world.

ANSWER.PARA: That conference came to the unanimous conclusion, particularly as the result of an Australian initiative, that there needed to be international co-operation to talk about what mutual assistance treaties would mean. They would mean countries giving financial records and information to other nations where that evidence would be of some interest in tracking criminals who were engaged in what is called pin stripe crime. Apart from gathering the evidence the honourable gentleman is adverting to the fact of being able to get the evidence readily analysed, assessed and dealt with in a very effective and expedient way. At present some trials run for very long periods. There has been some criticism that perhaps the juries may not readily understand all the ramifications. I am a very firm adherent to the jury system, and I do not know that the honourable gentleman is against that system. I understand the thrust of his question to be that perhaps there needs to be a different type of jury that might be able to assess some of the commercial problems submitted. It will always be necessary for law reform to be looking at this matter. I pay tribute to those who are actively engaged in the administration of justice in Australia, at both Federal and State levels, particularly in the courts. They see the need all the time to be suggesting reforms which will bring about justice in a fair, effective and cost-effective way. A committee has been virtually set up to talk about the effective administration of justice. It does not operate on an official basis but it is talking about ideas that might be thought through that would include matters such as this.

I make the point that the jury system is vital to our democratic society. We always recognise, though, that we might need certain aids for both judge and jury-that could mean part of the jury itself-so that there can be a ready analysis of the evidence submitted. More importantly, perhaps, there needs also to be reform so that evidence can be submitted more effectively and expeditiously than at present. All these matters are the subject of review.

I assure the honourable gentleman that getting the co-operation of everyone in Australia to do that is foremost in my mind, and I think we would have that co-operation. It is also clear that to get the initiative to bring these changes about we need to have the political will to do it, and that certainly obtains at this level. We would also need to convince the judges and administrators of justice that there are alternatives. I do not believe at this stage that we need to set up a special division of the Federal Court because the Court itself has sufficient qualifications to deal with matters commercial. I think the honourable gentleman's question relates to Federal criminal activity which is usually dealt with in the State courts. I am sure that we will get co-operation there. He has raised a number of interesting matters which will be the subject of continuing debate in this nation in the coming 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the briefing the Prime Minister has just received from his Minister for Defence on the subject, I ask whether the Prime Minister is aware that for logistical reasons nuclear powered ships are vital for the United States Navy's Indian Ocean patrols and that HMAS Stirling in Western Australia is an ideal port for rest and recreation for crews on those patrols because of its safety and suitability for handling nuclear powered vessels. In the light of the special relationship with the United States about which he has just advised us in answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question, can he advise the House what explanation he intends to offer to President Reagan for his Defence Minister seeking to follow the Lange line in requesting a reduction of United States naval vessel visits to Western Australian ports?

—This pathetic attempt by the shadow Minister for Defence to equate the clear position of the Australian Government's relationship with the United States of America with the quite separate and sovereignly independent position of New Zealand holds no water, as he knows. From the time when the difficulties between New Zealand and the United States emerged, the position of my Government has been made quite clear to and has been welcomed by the United States Government. None of his bluster will change the facts. The facts are clearly that the United States completely understands and accepts the policy position of the Australian Government, which policy position is calculated to maintain the security relationship of this country which exists under the ANZUS Treaty. It is a matter of regret to us, as I have publicly expressed and have also put to the United States Administration, that Australia no longer has a trilateral operation because of the impasse between New Zealand and the United States. In the meantime, we have ensured at the level of President and Prime Minister, Minister for Defence and Secretary for Defense, Secretary of State and Foreign Minister and at officials level that all discussions have taken place to ensure without any qualification the maintenance of the security relationship between this country and the United States. That is a fact which is understood and accepted here in Australia, in the United States of America and in New Zealand. The only place where apparently it is not accepted is in the minute mind of the shadow Minister for Defence. The facts are, as I have put them, that as a result of all the discussions that have been held at the presidential and prime ministerial level and at the level of the relevant Ministers, the United States has expressed its total confidence in and satisfaction with the arrangements made between this Government and the Government of the United States.

—My question, on the same subject, is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister seen claims by the Opposition defence spokesman that Australia is doing a Lange on the question of United States ship visits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the honourable member for her question because it enables me to make a point or two about the historic record of the Opposition in this regard and also clarify one or two points made quite erroneously in questions raised by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow defence spokesman. The first point I want to make is that, like most of the statements of the shadow Minister for Defence, what he said was absolute nonsense. He has followed up on his great Press release, which I managed to deal with the other day, in which he failed to recognise a reannouncement of his own policy with yet another statement which is, however, more mischievous than his initial failure. It represents what has been a long-standing effort by the Opposition to utilise matters related to the United States alliance not for debate on their intrinsic and essential merits in the area of national security but for political purposes in a way that has led a substantial proportion of the Australian population to mistrust the Opposition absolutely on this question. This has done material damage to the United States alliance, particularly among young people.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that we are not doing a Lange. American vessel visits to this country are welcome, and they are welcome in their present numbers. Those numbers are determined not by a port visit policy in this country but by the operational requirements of the United States Pacific Fleet. The number of visits to ports increases and reduces over time according to those operational requirements. So if in any particular period there is an operational requirement for more substantial numbers of ships to be in the Indian Ocean as opposed to the north-west Pacific, we are likely to get more port visits. For some considerable time United States policy has meant that that country has been interested in a wider variety of port visits in Australia. That is a standing position of the United States; it has been operational for some considerable time. This statement by the Opposition defence spokesman represents an example of the Opposition attempting to have its cake and eat it too. If we recollect past elements of the debate, accusations have come from the Opposition parties, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria, that there is a reluctance on the part of this Government and a certain reluctance on the part of State governments in New South Wales and Victoria to accept substantial numbers of or indeed any port visits by United States warships. An impression has been created over time by the Opposition-it does not reflect reality-that this Government is trying to isolate port visits to an area in Western Australia where it is known that they are politically welcome and that there is no problem there.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are.

—They are welcome; I agree. The Opposition states that there is a reluctance to see those visits take place elsewhere. That is a nonsense. The objective of discussions I had in the United States shows that that statement by the Opposition continues to be a nonsense. I discussed this matter with the relevant American officials when I was in the United States. There was not a reluctance to contemplate the possibility of more extensive port visits elsewhere in Australia, there was a positive delight in so contemplating. The Leader of the National Party pointed out quite correctly the desirability of Western Australia as a point of port access for operational purposes in the sense that American operation in the Indian Ocean requires a place for rest and recreation visits. In any adjustment to the relative numbers visiting different ports, that will be taken into account.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not the objective of this Government to impose unnecessary costs on the United States. The United States is not particularly worried about those additional costs. They are quite cheerful about the prospect of port visits elsewhere in the country. The Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party managed to pick up exactly the wrong end of the stick of this issue of our relationship with the American alliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a word to Gareth, he is Acting Foreign Minister.

—This represents a continuing of the very strong relationship we have with the United States. It was not implied either by the representative in the Senate that this represented a desire on our part to see a diminution of American port visits. Those opposite should read his answers in totality, not Press reports of them or other people's Press releases based on them. Given the number of port visits to this country, this policy may represent some degree of diminution in the number of visits to Western Australia and an increase in visits elsewhere, but it probably will not because that will depend on the aboslute number of port visits made by the United States. So an increasing number of Australians will experience port visits. We will not find ourselves in the situation in which the Opposition has accused us in the past-they have apparently forgotten-of being reluctant to accept port visits all over this country.

—I ask the Prime Minister whether he can assure the House that neither he, any member of his personal staff, nor any of his parliamentary colleagues was in any way involved in initiating or drafting the minute from Mr Visbord, the Acting Secretary to his Department, to the Prime Minister concerning the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Will he now table the minute, include the earlier drafts of that document, and the other documents which subsequently led to the minute being prepared?
—The minute I tabled in this House represented without qualification the opinion of Mr Visbord over whose signature the minute was tabled.

—I ask whether the Minister for Health is aware of the report appearing in this morning's Sydney Daily Telegraph claiming that `rebel doctors are planning to sabotage the Medicare system. Recommendations to this effect will be put to a meeting of surgeons in Sydney tomorrow'. Is he aware of statements made by the leader of these surgeons that the Federal Government has not moved at all on deregulation of private hospitals, one of the elements of the settlement package arrived at early this year? Can the Minister advise the House whether the Federal and New South Wales governments are fulfilling the commitments made to the medical profession following the doctors' dispute? What courses are available to the Government should the surgeons concerned embark on their self-proclaimed sabotage campaign? Have the doctors concerned been encouraged in their sabotage campaign by the reckless support of the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My notice has been drawn to the fact that the medical saboteurs of the New South Wales public hospital system are again raising their heads. They have the gall to question the Government's honouring of its commitments under the negotiated settlement. Two points are to be made about that group of procedural specialists in New South Wales. First, they are the people who did everything possible to sabotage the negotiated settlement and were overwhelmingly repudiated by the rest of the profession, both in New South Wales and in the country. Secondly, they are the people who in the newspapers this morning boasted that they have not returned to work, that they have not honoured the other side of the agreement. Yet these are the people who question the Government's performance.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has already honoured every immediate commitment it made in that negotiated settlement. The increased remuneration for doctors and the arbitration procedures have been carried through. Section 17 was repealed. The $50m capital funding for the public hospital system has been organised and is in the process of being paid to the States. The reclassification of patients as required has been carried through. The major health insurance changes have been made and the protection of community rating has been carried through in legislation. Every immediate commitment by the Government has been honoured. Yet we have not had the response from these people who now talk about questioning our commitments.

One part of the agreement is yet to be fulfilled. At the time it was made clear that the issue of the deregulation of private hospitals would take more time than any of the other commitments. That is because it is not just this Government that is involved, not just those few medical procedural friends of the Opposition; the issue of deregulation of the private hospitals in this country involves all the medical profession, all the State governments, the health insurance industry and the private hospitals. All those groups have made it clear that they will not be stampeded into decisions by this militant clique. Finally, let me say that while this Government subsidises the private hospital industry to some $140m a year, we will not resile from our commitment to protect taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Bradfield.

—I am sorry it is so boring, but the Government keeps giving us new information almost on the hour. In view of the Prime Minister's decision yesterday to restructure his Department to overcome his clear responsibility for the shambles he has created for the Australian Bicentennial, can he tell the House whether it is a fact that the first knowledge his Department had of Mr Reid's letter of 19 August, which contained details of the elements to be negotiated in the settlement with Dr Armstrong, was when he tabled it in this House on 19 September? Is it also a fact that the Prime Minister gave Mr Reid certain assurances sought in that letter during a telephone conversation with him on the same date? Why did he fail to bring the letter to his Department's attention earlier for information or advice or seek from the Department the letter relating to Dr Armstrong's appointment until after he had already approved the settlement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is typical of nearly everything that has been said by the Opposition in this case, the honourable member's question ended with a misrepresentation. He referred to my approval of the settlement. If the honourable member for Bradfield would take the trouble to look at the documents which have been tabled in this House he would see that the very essence of the letter of 30 August, which was written by me after advice taken from the Department on receipt of the letter from Mr Reid on 28 August, was to point out to Mr Reid, the Chairman of the ABA, that under the legislation-legislation brought in by the former Government-I had no authority to approve or otherwise. The quality of the question that has been addressed to me may be adjudged by the fact that those opposite still insist on a grotesque misrepresentation of what happened in this case. I repeat, in the hope-probably unfounded-that even the dull member for Bradfield will understand, at this late stage, if he has not to this point, that under the legislation for which honourable members opposite were responsible I had no authority to approve the settlement, and I did not approve it. In those circumstances the whole of the honourable member's question falls to the ground because it is posited on a complete misrepresentation.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts relating to the conversation of 19 August are quite clear. They were based upon my having spoken to Mr Reid on 15 August. I will state the facts again. As I said, hopefully the honourable member will understand. On 15 August I indicated to Mr Reid my belief that the services of Dr Armstrong should be terminated. I put that to the Chairman. He said to me that he would go away and think about it. That he did, and also he had conversations with Dr Armstrong. He spoke to me on the telephone on 19 August, the day the honourable member mentioned, and on that day I had already received from him the letter of that date in which he set out certain factors which he would regard as relevant. Let me make it clear again that in that conversation Mr Reid made it clear that the order of the amount that would be involved related to the fact, as he put it, that there would be six years of the contract to buy out. That measures the order of the figure that has been talked about. He insisted in that conversation-I hope that the honourable member will get this through his thick head-that as a matter of law and propriety he would conduct those negotiations. That was his job and his responsibility and he went away to do it.

Following the carrying out of those negotiations, as Mr Reid insisted he would do, on the basis of this contract to buy out for six years, a letter came back dated 28 August. I took advice on that matter. The advice I received was the appropriate advice not merely from my Department but also from the Attorney-General's Department to my Department that I had no authority under the law to approve the settlement. I wrote to Mr Reid in those terms. It is crystal clear, therefore, as it has been since I tabled these matters in the House, that I did not approve the settlement, as I did not have the authority to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Science aware of the expedition to the Antarctic being organised by the Greenpeace organisation? Can he advise on the capabilities of the expedition and, more particularly, the capabilities of the vessel to cope with the difficult and dangerous conditions it is likely to encounter in the Antarctic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the planned expedition. Greenpeace plans to send a vessel to the Antarctic this summer to set up a four-man wintering station. It is planned that the expedition will leave either Sydney or Hobart in late November or early December. Under the Antarctic Treaty, the nation from which an expedition departs has an obligation to report details of that expedition to other Treaty nations. The provision of these details is regarded as essential for the safe conduct of expeditions since it provides Antarctic Treaty nations with information on all operations there, enabling help to be quickly given or sought in an emergency.

ANSWER.PARA: The Greenpeace organisation was requested by letter on 21 June to provide the necessary details to this Government for distribution to Treaty nations. It was acknowledged on 31 July, but the full information required has not been provided. This hampers Australia in discharging its obligations under the Treaty and also raises very serious doubts about the ability of the expedition to cope with Antarctic conditions without seeking assistance from other nations. In particular, there are doubts about the vessel named Greenpeace, which is an ocean-going tug from Baltimore, registered in Miami. We are told that it has been strengthened in some ways by modification in Amsterdam with additional frames, bow plating and protection for the propeller and the rudder. These modifications were meant to improve the performance in ice conditions, but its ice capability has not been advised. It is not known whether the ship was insured and it is admitted that the vessel does not have a Lloyd's survey covering ice classification. We have no information about the crew's experience in Antarctic waters or work in ice conditions generally. There is no clear information about the vessel's route, the exact location of the over-wintering base that Greenpeace intends to set up or details of the crew's programs

I say this to the House: As the rendering of assistance to this expedition by Australian or other nations would hamper programs and involve risks to personnel and equipment and could prove costly, we must continue to seek further information on the self-sufficiency of the expedition. I say this to the Greenpeace people: Remember that ice beat Napoleon, and it may be that there will be a similar fate for Greenpeace. In the view of the Government the crew faces quite unacceptable risk. We cannot stop the expedition as we have no legal power to do so, but we have a moral obligation to warn Greenpeace and those people who support the expedition here that it runs a quite unacceptable risk of being stuck in a situation in which we will be powerless to assist. I think, because of that, Greenpeace itself should make a decision not to go. However much we respect the organisation's motives for going to the Antarctic, that risk-35 lives might be put at risk, and it would be quite outside the physical power of Australia to come to the crew's assistance-is in our view much too high. This view has been put very strongly by the Department of Foreign Affairs and my own Department without avail, so far as Greenpeace is concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the well publicised advice of his close and warm colleague Senator Richardson that three scapegoats should be found for the Prime Minister's incompetent handling of the Australian Bictentennial Authority affair. I ask: Has he taken that advice? Have any officers of his Department been demoted, relieved, disciplined or transferred? If so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have to say that I have received no such advice. If I may lapse into the Australian vernacular, which is good enough for me: I received no such advice from my good friend and colleague Senator Richardson. He said nothing about looking for scapegoats. Mr Speaker, as I made clear to the House yesterday, there was an awareness within the Department itself that there had been incompetence. I certainly had some rather harsh words to say to those involved. In the event, I am able to say to the House that the acting permanent head of my Department has proposed certain changes to the Department. He made those proposals to me this morning. I have endorsed them and asked that they proceed. These involve the establishment of a separate Bicentennial Division in my Department under Mr Ron Harvey. It will be supported by two branches. It will report to Mr Neil McInnes, a Deputy Secretary in the Department. I believe that all those honourable members who know Mr Harvey will share the very considerable confidence in him that I have.
—How much will it cost-$500,000?

—Now we are asked how much that will cost. Honourable members opposite cannot have it both ways. They want to say that there is a problem. They say that the situation has not been handled correctly. I immediately take moves to ensure that there will be a division set up within the Prime Minister's Department to handle this. What is the miserable little reaction of honourable members opposite? They ask how much it will cost. Honourable members opposite ought to make up their minds about which way they are going on this issue. The reason why there has been extreme difficulty in the handling of this matter is that honourable members opposite passed legislation which created very considerable difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is appropriate that it be on record that it is not just the present Prime Minister who inherited the mess of the past who feels that this is so; it is somewhat relevant to know what the Prime Minister of the time, Mr Fraser, has now had to say about this matter. If I say that the legislative arrangements that were made then were unsatisfactory, honourable members opposite may not take any notice of that because of the way their little minds work. Perhaps honourable members opposite have not distanced themselves so far at this stage from their previous leader as to ignore what he has had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?

—Mr Malcolm Fraser. I think it would be a matter of some interest to hear what Mr Malcolm Fraser had to say on this subject on 2 October. I have a transcript of an interview of Mr Fraser by Jane Singleton, an interviewer of whom I am aware. I know she is a real person. Mr Malcolm Fraser stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Some time ago I wrote a letter to the Authority about the programs that the Authority was developing and I don't think that they depicted adequately the nature of Australia and what Australia is about. I had my own arguments on that basis with the Authority. Resignation payment, or whatever one might call it for Mr Armstrong, was a total nonsense and quite unjustifiable. If the Prime Minister is not happy with the way things have moved up to this point, nor am I.
He went on to talk about the problems with the structure of the Authority. He said:

. . . all I can say is we thought we were doing this sensibly at the time. It was supported by the Parliament and I think virtually unanimously, I'm not aware of anyone having voted against the legislation that was established. One of the things I've come to reflect upon, having been out of Parliament, is that independent commissions are generally a bad thing because Ministers and Departments ought to maintain control because Ministers can be made accountable through the Parliament.
There honourable members opposite have their own previous Leader--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that honourable members on my left show some respect for the House and remain silent.

—As usual on this matter, honourable members opposite are completely incapable of following the logic and the facts of what is being said. The Prime Minister of the time, Mr Fraser, is saying that because of the way in which the Authority was set up the possibility of having proper ministerial accountability and control was made more difficult. That is the point I have been making. Obviously, in hindsight, Mr Fraser is contemplating that it would have been sensible to do it in another way. I believe that is the case. If in fact we had not had the arm's length situation which was created by honourable members opposite, the sort of control that one would wish to have in fact would be easier to have. I am simply saying that what we have done now, in the circumstances of legislation passed by honourable members opposite, is decided to establish a new division within my Department which, within the difficulties created by that legislation, will provide a better opportunity of control and accountability so far as that is possible under the legislation passed by honourable members opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members opposite cannot have it both ways. Honourable members opposite, by their legislation, have created difficulties and difficulties have emerged. We have now moved to create a new division to try to have the best possible control and accountability. Honourable members opposite should not come up now with nonsensical interventions about how much it will cost. Either honourable members opposite want to have the best sort of system or they do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer advise the House whether the Government has finalised its taxation reform package? How does the Government's progress in this area compare with that of other groups in the community which purport to have an interest in developing policy on taxation?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This question is canvassing a matter which is currently before the House. The tax reform package is currently under debate and legislation is before the Parliament. It is not proper under our Standing Orders for such matters to be canvassed at Question Time.
—Order! The honourable member has asked whether the tax reform package has been finalised, not about the specific question of the tax reform package.
—Mr Speaker, in those circumstances, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The implications for the principle of ministerial responsibility arising out of the Prime Minister's handling of the $500,000 payment to the former Chief Executive of the Australian Bicentennial Authority.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those souls on the other side of the House who may have imagined a couple of days ago that this matter was dead, buried and finished might feel a bit disappointed today that it is very much alive and kicking. Honourable members opposite might also reflect for a moment on the fact that the one person they have to thank for that is their own Leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). If ever a person revived something on its death bed-I have to confess that it was just about running out in political terms-the Prime Minister did so. There he goes, running out of the House. That is the sort of regard the Prime Minister of this country has for the concept of ministerial responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: On earlier occasions the Prime Minister may have deflected ministerial responsibility from himself. He may not have taken the matter as seriously as the Opposition and the public of Australia would have liked him to do. But over the last 24 hours the Prime Minister has turned the principle of ministerial responsibility on its head. The Prime Minister of this country has established a new principle: The greater your blame, the deeper your implication and the more you are responsible for a mess, the more scapegoats you find. The real architect of the shambles of the last few weeks relating to the Australian Bicentennial Authority is not the former Chief Executive, it is not the former Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority and it is not the three officers of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet who have apparently been demoted because of their role in the matter; the real person to blame and the man who does not have the courage to cop it and to admit responsibility for it is the Prime Minister of this country who has just walked out of the chamber.

Over the last 48 hours the Prime Minister has added political cowardice to deceit and incompetence in his handling of this matter. On 11 September he dissembled to the Australian public a pretence that he had nothing to do with it. When he was found out on that he tried to blame Mr Reid. He tried to seek refuge in the opinion of the Solicitor-General. He came running into the Parliament in response to a matter of public importance and he huffed and puffed himself up and right at the end one could see him shaking with excitement when he announced: `Here is the king hit; here is the report of the Solicitor-General. That is going to fix you; that is going to silence you'. Unfortunately, it was one of those reverse exocets because instead of king hitting those on this side of the House who brought the Prime Minister into account, it swung right around and king hit the Prime Minister.

It demonstrated two things. It demonstrated that if only the Prime Minister had exercised normal administrative prudence and gone to his Department on the 15, 16, 17, 18 or 19 August and said: `Look, this is what I am going to do. Will you tell me whether it is okay? Will you go and talk to Trevor Boucher and get him to check out the tax aspects? Will you go to the Attorney-General's Department? Will you talk to the Solicitor-General? It is $400,000 and we are dealing with the Chief Executive of the Authority. Is it okay? Am I doing the right thing by the public? Am I discharging my ministerial responsibilities?' But, no, that is too simple a suggestion for this man and his minders. He decides to do it all himself. The inevitable question is asked: But if the Solicitor-General's opinion was so crash hot, why on earth was it not obtained before the horse had bolted? Why was it not obtained before the money had been paid over? Why on earth was it not obtained before the Prime Minister had said: `Yes, good on you. Err on the side of generosity. Thanks, John, for doing such a terrific job?

The other question that is raised is that if in fact it was not so crash hot, if the Prime Minister's original view on 17 September was that the opinion of Allen, Allen and Helmsley was okay, what grounds were there for dismissing Mr John Reid, particularly as the report of the Solicitor-General on the subject of tax minimisation significantly enough did not say there was any tax minimisation? What did the report of the Solicitor-General say about tax minimisation? It completely cleared Mr Reid of any implication regarding tax minimisation. That report was completely unable to support the claim made by the Prime Minister that the whole arrangement had the colour of tax minimisation.

Either way, that particular little king hit turned out to be a reverse exocet and the matter was back on the front pages and up and running again, not so much because of arguments that have been put but because of the Prime Minister's craven inability to understand one simple fact. That fact is that once a Minister is caught out and has made a mistake, the best thing to do is to come into this place and say: `I made a mistake. I accept responsibility for it. I will see that it does not happen again and I will try to lift my game to ensure that it does not happen again.' However, if there is one thing we now know for certain it is that one cannot ask this Prime Minister to ever do that. The more he is caught out, the more he is to blame and the deeper he is in we know what he will do-he will blame others. He blames Reid. He blames the Opposition. He blames his Department. He blames the public. He blames everybody, of course, but himself.

There is a simple rule now that if anybody wants to stay in his job he must either be a Minister in this Government or a State secretary of the ALP. The other thing that we are interested in demonstrating this week is the double standard of this Prime Minister when it comes to misconduct. Apparently a Governor, who according to the Premier of Victoria accepted a free trip, has to go but a State secretary who engages in political dirty tricks can stay in his job. That is the sort of standard that rules in the Labor Party in Victoria, the home State of the Prime Minister.

This little episode has been brought along and kept going by that first great reverse exocet. The second great reverse exocet was delivered by none other than the great number cruncher from Sydney, Senator Graham Richardson, seen scurrying in and out of the Prime Minister's office most of yesterday afternoon, no doubt trying his hand with a little bit of drafting here and there and no doubt making a lot of suggestions. He appeared on radio station 2GB and said that it was absolutely terrible that people cannot rely on anybody these days and that poor old Bob had been let down by all those bunglers in his Department. There was no mention of the fact, of course, that bungler Bob had not even told his Department about it. He kept them in the dark. It is bad enough a Minister shirking his ministerial responsibilities when in reality his Department was told everything and he sticks to the Westminster principle because in the long run if one is to have respect and support from his department one has to endure, to some extent, the thick and thin of the competence or otherwise of his department. However, it is a bit rough on a department when it gets kept in the dark and then it gets blamed to boot. That is what happened with the Prime Minister's Department.

The most critical failure in this whole issue was the fact that the Prime Minister did not send Mr Reid's letter of 19 August to his Department. The first time the Prime Minister's Department knew about that letter of 19 August was when it was tabled here one month later, namely, 19 September. According to the evidence before the Senate Estimates Committee, Mr Rose of the Prime Minister's Department said: `We were completely in the dark until we got the letter of 28 August. We did not really know the background of it'. It really is a bit rough. It is one thing to blame your department, to publicly humiliate it and to extract a most cringing and humiliating confession from your Department when it has not been kept in the picture. It is the height of shabby treatment for a Prime Minister to kick his Department to death when in fact he has kept it in the dark. He has led his Department up the garden path. The people who have been misled by this have been the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the public of Australia. They are the people who have been misled, and not the Prime Minister of this country.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen the most monumental exercise in turning the very principle of ministerial responsibility on its head. We have a new Hawke's edition of May's Parliamentary Practice dealing with ministerial responsibility. He has written a new chapter on ministerial responsibility according to Bob Hawke. That chapter says that the only principle that applies is that you never resign, you never say you are sorry, you blame somebody else and above everything you never admit that you could ever possibly make a mistake. That is the principle by which this Prime Minister has lived and behaved throughout the whole of this episode. That particular piece of conduct makes very strange comparison with some of the utterances and immortal words of his colleagues on the subject of ministerial responsibility. Back on 25 August 1982:
Ministerial responsibility, I remind the honourable members, does not concern the question of what one knew; it concerns the question of what one ought to have known.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That is the Deputy Prime Minister, the present Attorney-General, the first law officer of the Commonwealth. He ought to know something about ministerial responsibility. However, let us go on because it gets better. On 25 August 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: If actions (of Ministers) in their Department are such that a scandal is created-
honourable members have to admit that has happened here-
and someone should take the blame, they should be men enough to stand up and say: `We should have known about this'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). It gets even better. The shorter it is the better it gets. On 7 September 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: Ignorance is no excuse.

That was the present Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). But the climax is really this-coming right up to date on 27 March 1985, only this year. Labor was in government then and could not claim refuge in the proposition that when in opposition one blurs the position a little. This is what the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said. He said that he did not blame departmental officials. He went on: `It is a matter of who is the boss-the Minister at the time'. That happened to be the view of none other than the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General. It is no wonder that the Prime Minister has walked out on the debate on this matter of public importance. It is no wonder that he failed to answer any questions directly and honestly on this matter today. It is no wonder that he refused to tell the Deputy Leader of the Opposition whether some of his minders had heavied anybody in his Department on that minute. It is no wonder he cut and ran on that subject. It is no wonder he has refused from the very beginning to give a straight answer on this subject to the Opposition. It is no wonder that day by day he has got deeper and deeper into the mess on this subject because he will not accept one simple code of conduct that somebody at the peak of a government has to accept, that ultimately if one makes a mistake, one must have the courage to admit it, own up to it and stop blaming other people.

This Prime Minister has been guilty of a lot of things and a lot of mistakes on this matter. His administrative competence has been shockingly short of reasonable requirements for a Prime Minister. He has bullied; he has hectored; he has abused; he has dishonoured the trust of leading businessmen in this country who sought to serve the Government in an honourable fashion. He has deceived the public. He has misled this Parliament. His ministerial standards have been poor, his adminstration has been sloppy. He has sought to have it both ways. He has walked out of the chamber but to his incompetence and his dishonesty and the way in which he has misled the Parliament, he has added one other very important and crucial failing for a person who is the leader of a government. It may be bad enough that a Prime Minister's administrative abilities have been found wanting. It may be bad enough that in this whole sorry affair he has been shown as a person who normally does not take prudent advice. It may be bad enough that he sacked somebody in the person of John Reid who was doing no more than the Prime Minister's bidding throughout the whole of the affair, but of all the things the Prime Minister has done wrong, the one that condemns him most and the one that I believe the Australian people will hold against him the most is that at the end of the day when he was caught out, when he had nowhere to turn, he did not have the courage to say: `I am to blame for this. We are all human. I will see it does not happen again'. He could not bring himself to do that. He had to seek cowardly refuge in blaming others, casting around for scapegoats among public servants, businessmen and, who knows, among people on his own personal staff. I believe that that piece of political cowardice of the Prime Minister is the worst feature of his conduct in this whole affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew the day would have to come when someone from the former Fraser Ministry would have the gall to talk about ministerial propriety in this place. Ministers in that Government were the greatest bunch of blunderers this country had seen since World War II. We can go through a whole regime of ministerial misdemeanours during the period 1975 to 1983 under the leadership of Malcolm Fraser. Yet the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) got up in this House today and spoke about the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the events of the Australian Bicentennial Authority as if they were far and above more important than some of the issues that occurred during 1975 to 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: One can readily understand why members of the Opposition wish to continue talking about the Bicentenary in view of the news yesterday that another 57,000 jobs had been created under this Government, making in two-and-half years 487,000 new jobs. Why would not Opposition members want to talk about the Bicentenary? They do not want to talk about the economy; they do not want to talk about jobs; they do not want to talk about the centralised wage fixing system which has given everybody the opportunity to get proper and increasing economic growth in this country. They want to talk about the Bicentenary, which no one else in Australia was talking about. They were all talking about more important issues, as they should. If Opposition members want to talk about the Bicentenary, I suggest we should compare our per- formance in government with their performance in government in that period of almost eight years.

There are three classic examples of what the Fraser Government did about ministerial behaviour. First, I refer to the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the Leader of the National Party, on the question of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. In 1981 a Senate committee found on the balance of probabilities that Mr Sinclair was told that a rebate arrangement by Asia Dairy Industries involved a breach of a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangement. The committee also referred to financial irregularities in the operation of the Australian Dairy Corporation and a lack of accountability. What happened to Mr Sinclair? He stayed in the Cabinet up until the Government was defeated in 1983, and now he sits opposite as a person who wants to be Deputy Prime Minister of this country under the leadership of Mr Howard. So much for ministerial behaviour. In 1982 Mr Justice Woodward in the Report of the Royal Commission on the Australian Meat Industry said:
I am bound to record my view that the Minister, Mr Nixon, did not deal with the allegations adequately and effectively.

Mr Nixon submitted his resignation which was not accepted by Mr Fraser, who in turn proceeded to do a hatchet job on the Royal Commissioner. When the Royal Commissioner said that the Minister was responsible and should accept responsibility for what had occurred during this unhappy episode, Mr Fraser got up here, exactly where I am standing today, and said that the Royal Commission had got it all wrong. He said: `My Minister is innocent, irrespective of what the Royal Commissioner said'. And what happened to Mr Nixon? He stayed in the Cabinet again up until the Government was defeated in 1983.

If Opposition members want to talk about ministerial behaviour, in 1982 there was another classic example, when the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union made devastating criticism of the administration of the Attorney-General's Department and revealed the scandal of the previous Government's total neglect of the tax system which allowed the growth of the tax avoidance industry. Both Senator Durack and Mr Howard then blamed everybody else except themselves. Where is Senator Durack today? He was Attorney-General during the time of the Costigan report which found the Attorney-General's Department guilty of neglect, especially in the Western Australian office, but Senator Durack was there right up until 1983. Now he sits in the Senate, waiting for the emergence of another Liberal-National Party government when he will be Attorney-General again, in spite of what Mr Costigan said. Was not Costigan's a lovely report? Tax evasion files were being put into drawers and forgotten about. The House will also remember the classic description by Mr Costigan in his report about what was happening. The Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Western Australia was running a call girl racket from the Attorney-General's Department. A caller would ring up and they would reply: `Can I be of service? Who are you calling?'. The caller would say, `I want the Attorney-General's Department'. They would say: `Well, it is $40 for a short time'. The caller would say: `What are you talking about?'. They were running a call girl racket from the Attorney-General's Department in Western Australia, and Senator Durack is going to be the next Attorney-General in an incoming Liberal- National Party government. So let us compare just those three illustrations of what occurred between 1975 and 1983 with what Opposition members are talking about today. Let me tell the House what Senator Durack said when the criticism was made of him. I quote from the Hansard of 7 September 1982:

Senator Button suggests that I am to be criticised because I said that I knew nothing about the mismanagement over a particular period of a tax file in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. I suppose that something new since we had the earlier debate is that on a Nationwide program reference has been made to a file and opinion given in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney. The honourable senator asks why I did not know about that either. The fact is that I did not know about either the Brinsden opinion or the Lockhart opinion until recently. The reason is that the officers of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, although within my Department, deal with a large number of cases. That is the business of the officers; they do not keep telling me what they are doing from day to day or from week to week. This is the most childish conception of ministerial responsibility. How on earth does anybody believe in this day and age, with departments as large as they are and with the enormous activities of government, that Ministers can know or ought to know of all the ramifications of the actions of their departments.

So said Senator Durack in 1982. Now we have a complaint from the Leader of the Opposition that the Prime Minister, personally, in February of this year, when all the files of the Department of Administrative Services were handed over to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, should have sat down and gone through all of them to see what was on record and then taken responsibility for it.

The Leader of the Opposition says today how terrible it is that the Prime Minister of this country should criticise a couple of public servants. He is lucky that Clyde Cameron is not here to talk about the Public Service. If he were, the honourable gentleman would have heard a lot more about it. Let me tell the Leader of the Opposition this, if he is listening in his little cubbyhouse wondering what is going to happen to him in the future: This country would have been a lot beter off if in the period from 1977 to 1983, when he was Treasurer, he had spoken to John Stone in the way the present Prime Minister talked to his public servants yesterday about their responsibility. The fact that the Leader of the Opposition allowed John Stone to put all his policies into operation in that period and to treat him with absolute contempt meant that we kept getting more and more unemployment. The John Stones of the world have a crisis mentality. They do not believe that economic problems can be solved with full employment. The John Stones of the world are happy if there is 20 or 30 per cent unemployment and nil inflation. That is the person the honourable member for Bennelong should have stood up against between 1977 and 1983.

The honourable member for Bennelong also talks about ministerial responsibility. John Stone came along before the 1983 election and said to the honourable member: `Minister, I think we are approaching something like a $9.6 billion deficit this year'. What did the honourable member for Bennelong do, as he always did? He went running off to Malcolm. He said: `Malcolm, look what we have got. We have this horrible thing. I have just been advised by Treasury that we are going to have a $9.6 billion deficit in 1983-84. Should we tell the public? Malcolm said: `Break it up. We are not going to tell them now. It is only three weeks before the election. Go and hide yourself'. (Quorum formed)

The Leader of the Opposition put the proposition to us just 10 or 15 minutes ago that the Prime Minister should be honest with us, tell us everything that went on, and admit that he had made a mistake. I refer honourable members to the actions and activities of the Leader of the Opposition, when Treasurer of this country, in the weeks leading up to the 1983 election. He had been told by the Treasury what was going to happen to the deficit in 1983-84. The honourable member was interviewed on 21 February 1983, just before the election. He was asked:
If you are still the Federal Treasurer in August, what will be the size of your deficit?
The honourable member answered:
I really cannot say at this stage because it's too early in the piece. On present indications it would be trending higher than the existing deficit of about $4,000 million.
He said it was trending higher than the existing deficit of $4 billion when he had already been told by John Stone that it was going to be $9.6 billion.

Who has done the most damage to this country? Let us compare the activities of the Leader of the Opposition between 1977 and 1983, up to and including his role in misleading the Australian public during the 1983 election campaign, with what we have had in the debate about the Australian Bicentennial Authority. What the Prime Minister did in respect of the Bicentennial Authority has proved to be absolutely correct, and it has been backed up by the Opposition's former leader, for whom they now do not have much respect. Big Mal, who had them all terrified when he was here, told them today that if he were to do it again he would set up the Authority quite differently from the way he did it in 1980. Also at today's Board meeting was the person who played the more constructive role in trying to get things back on the track and the Authority working towards 1988, the former leader of the National Party of Australia, Doug Anthony.

It is only the very small group which sits in opposition, the Liberal and National parties, which wants to carry on the fight about the Bicentennial. As I said at the outset of this debate, the reason members of the Opposition want to talk about the Bicentennial is that they do not have any right to go out into the community and talk about any of the other issues. How many of them are going to go home at the weekend and say to their constituents: `Isn't it terrific? Another 57,000 people are in jobs since last month. We can take some credit because we are in the national Parliament and we have 57,000 more people working this month than were working last month. There are now 487,000 more people working in this country than there were at the time of the summit in 1983'. No, that is of no interest to them. Really, they want interest rates on housing loans at 25 per cent, they want a 25 per cent inflation rate, and they want 15 to 20 per cent unemployment, as in Britain. Then they will really be happy. They will all be sitting up looking very gleeful when Australia has the economic circumstances which might catapult them back into office. What the Opposition really cannot come to grips with is the fact that this country has a very good government. This is the first week in the 12 years I have been a member of this place that I have ever seen the Opposition discipline its back bench by not allowing them to ask one question. Opposition back benchers have not asked one question. They were told: `Please do not ask about any economic issues. Let us continue all this week to talk about the Bicentennary'. The Opposition wants that to be the major issue in the country.

We still have a long way to go. We still have 8.1 per cent unemployment. We have brought it down from 10.2 per cent. We have tens of thousands more people in houses than would have been the case if we had not introduced the first home owners scheme. Magnificent strides forward have been made in almost every facet of Australian living as a result of the election of the Hawke Labor Government in 1983. They are the important issues to the Australian people. We will get the Bicentennial Authority back on the track and everybody will be able to enjoy the fruits of that effort in the festivities of 1988. The Opposition, through its Leader, can get up here and yelp and howl about the Bicentennial for as long as it likes. The real crunch issues, which are the issues that put it out of office in 1983, are going to be the issues that keep us in office in 1987. I hope, and I am sure everybody on the Government side of the House hopes that the Opposition continues to talk about the Bicentennial while we keep putting the runs on the board.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Patients
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85% of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that does not exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
